review:
Игра понравилась. Особенностями этого симулятора является то, что здесь зарабатываешь на транспортировке, а любые постройки, которые ты оплачиваешь тебе не принадлежат и ими пользуются и твои конкуренты. Идея игры - обойти конкурентов в заработке, для чего создаешь и настраиваешь маршруты, покупаешь грузовые корабли и создаешь хабы с дронами-доставщиками грузов.
Основнаые проблемы игры:
- интерфейс совсем не интуитивный. Не сразу разберешься как работают настройки загрузки и выгрузки товаров в маршрутах. Например если товар в избытке (Surplus) на обеих планетах маршрута, но ты хочешь его накопить на одной из них, то со стандартными настроками маршрута корабль просто будет возить один и тот же груз туда-сюда. Нужно запретить загружать этот груз в пунтке выгрузки в настройках маршрута. Поскольку корабли двигаются не очень быстро, то пока заметишь, разберешься и исправишь пройдет несколько лет.
 - не сбалансировано производство воды и очень медленное развитие колоний (0,0001% в неделю), которое невозможно никаким образом ускорить. Без воды в других системах приходится тащить ее с Земли, и на Земле возникает пробка из кораблей в ожидании, с которой ничего не сделаешь - развитие космопорта ограничено 14м уровнем. Также не встречается планет, которые можно было бы развить до уровня главной планеты (Земли). То есть развить соседнюю звездную систему до уровня солнечной системы невозможно, хотя именно этого и хочется. Также на Земле невозможно вырастить население выше 7 млрд человек. Когда понимаешь, что раскачать другие звезды до приличного населения невозможно, тут и теряешь интерес.

review:
This is a nice little cozy game, with a lot of micro-management and a semi-deep gameplay system. I enjoyed all my time with the game, and it seems to make the time go by really fast.
Overall this gets my recommendation, but at a 10-15 Euro pricepoint, it was fun and the solely responsible game was for me a blast as you didn't have to handle those pesky opponents.
A few things that detracted from the experience:
- I really missed that there was some type of interaction with other companies, like purchasing or sabotaging, or just anything, currently they are just there.
- The tech tree could really use some "automation" features, as when your systems become really big they are really hard to maintain, and the amount of Micro needed is well too much.
- I think the game itself wants you to do these 2 hour games where you optimize and then the game is done after 50 years, but it really feels like its more fun to build out your empire, there just isnt much to do after 75 years that is new in any way.

Still recommended due the fun i had, but a bit shallow in the gameplay.

review:
I put a positive reviewe, but it's more of a mixed one.

First, I only play in the hardest difficulty in solo (no AI).
We start with absolutely nothing, no landing pad on earth, no spaceship, no colonies, and every very small starting capital.

So it's time to start the perilous adventure ofopening some gates n Earth and launch rockets on the Moon...

And be really quick to build bigger gates, open gates on the moon and buy your first reusable ship, because very soon, demand on the Moon will be too low to make rockets profitable, and if you wait too long between launches, the gates lease will chew your capital and the Moon colony will fail.

And after, that, time to expenda your empire, slowly, very slowly through the solar system, be careful not to overspend, don't be scared to starve colonies to make better profits, manage your funds to improve your research and at some point...


You'll reach boredom before settling in the first outer world.

When you are done with research, you have basically reached the endgame, and at that point, well, there is no real point in continuing playing, you only buy more ships to settle on more worlds, to make more money, to buy more ships to settle on more worlds, etc...

simply put, the game gets very repetitive and you're not even out of the solar system yet.

You need more resources to keep your colonies alive, but the solar system is pretty much self-sufficient, so importing exotic resources is not really worth it.

I get that playing against AI or human competitors, the market would be oversaturated, making it mandatory to find new opportunities elsewhere. But ironically, the hardest game mode doesn't have such a necessity.

I think the game stopped development too soon, the game lacks in-depth, and nothing pushes the player to go further.
Having projects like terraforming or megastructures, consuming a lot of resources and pushing the player to find exotic resources would have been a nice touch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993210208', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1649049459}
review:
This is like 80% of the way to a good game.

And I don't mean like it needs some visual polish to fix things like the camera vibrating as it tries to follow a moon around its orbit and things not quite syncing up right, or having the camera sometimes zoom in (while panning...) so close you see only empty space until you zoom out again.

No. While all of that is true, the main problem is three fold:

1) Single-use rockets are [b]incredibly[/b] cost effective. Most planets have little value in terms of exports, so why send a reusable slow-boat with high capacity for 100 times the purchase price (adding fuel costs, degradation upkeep costs, and so on) when you could instead send 100 single use rockets?

2) The AI isn't all that smart. Sure it can change up its strategy instantly as soon as conditions change and you can't, but it doesn't realize that half the rockets it's sending [i]have no cargo at all[/i] and the AI player would either eventually go bankrupt or would just barely survive out of sheer luck, but as a result never fold and give the player a win. But that leads me to...

3) The colony ships Earth sends out (an AI algorithm that isn't a player) picks the worst targets. First interstellar target is the nearest star? Haha nope, it'll be the one way out here, target moon? 3% habitability with no resources. [b]Every single extrasolar colony I did not finance was useless[/b], and because they were so far away, would collapse due to a lack of food/water before any could even be delivered (you can't set up a trade route and send resources until the colony ship arrives...)

I had some other issues, like Luna not allowing me to build an office (which raises my company standing) because my company standing was too low (at 80%...) and my standing would continuously degrade month after month because...their import demands was too high...at 0% (literally between me and the AI player(s) we were meeting all of their needs to the point that it wasn't profitable). But those were all minor problems.

It's the balance problems lead to a very shallow, very boring experience.

But hey, it has multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030385006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1687083968}
review:
Excellent jeu de gestion pour celles et ceux qui se projettent dans le Space Opera, et tout sa dimension matérielle-commerciale. Même en mode facile, l'IA va commander moult vaisseaux pour vous concurrencer, ce qui vous pousse à être toujours sur le qui-vive comme le meilleur des capitalistes spatiaux. Système d'offre et demande  simple mais dynamique, qui vous force à reconfigurer régulièrement vos vaisseaux pour s'adapter au marché. Certes, le jeu est un peu répétitif, mais il l'est de façon amusante (plus les planètes sont colonisées, plus elles produisent des ressources diversifiées, vous amenant à penser les meilleures routes, configurations de vaisseaux). 

Point négatif : l'interface pourrait être optimisée (texte un peu petit, menus qui parfois disparaissent ou se télescopent). 
On pourrait aussi regretter l'absence de côté "qualitatif", de personnalisation de sa compagnie spatiale : le temps est plus passé à optimiser son compte de résultat sur chaque ligne qu'à renommer ses petits vaisseaux et donner une touche personnelle à sa compagnie. 

On pardonne les quelque défauts parce que c'est vraiment un jeu original et très plaisant pour les amateurs de SF.

review:
I was going to write a bad review of this game at first but the more I thought about it the more I realized that I have gotten a good amount of hours of enjoyment for the money I paid. 

I do have some frustrations with with the game. The main game loop of building a transport company move to good from production planets to demand planets is a really fun game loop. Sadly this is where the game loop begins to break down since the economy of goods is not very well consumed so at some point in time you find that shipping goods becomes harder and harder since planets need less and less. 

The developers are working on resolving this since they have added in a mechanic where the homeworld will spawn seed ship to a second M class planet in range of your homeworld. The issue i have is that it does not seem to be triggered by the fact that your home planet is overflowing with resources.

review:
Could be an ok game but sadly the balance is bad and kills any long term reason to go for "mid/end" game. In the start-phase it's working ok but you will quickly lose the AI to their bankruptcy in later stages of the game.

Also the GUI is quite bad especially if you start to have many ships/trade routes and/or the various planets start to fill up.

So whats killing the balance?
Some important techs that you can research destroy the supply/demand ratio of the goods killing the prices. The AI can't handle this and will quickly go bankrupt after you start to use this techs. Also one shots rockets nearly always offer a much too good revenue often much better than regular ships killing the "transport tycoon" feeling quite a lot and this can easily be abused to kill the AI even quicker by saturation short time demands as the AI tries to use mostly slow moving ships in later phases.

So sadly a thumbs down ..

review: The entire game has a very low-budget and tacky feel to it, with things like scrolling not always working and off-screen tooltip/UI incredibly common. The graphics aren't absolutely terrible, but they're ugly enough. It's also not possible to cancel ships that are being built without clicking the sell button, which of course makes you lose money. Most importantly, it's incredibly easy to be a victim of your own success and oversupply a port, which is why the AI uses single-use rockets like 75% of the time, and then barely manages to turn a profit. I don't mind a bit of micromanagement, but this game requires a lot of clicking and scrolling in a low-quality interface to even be playable, and even then it's still not that fun. Ultimately, this game is basically an unfinished game that presents itself as one (and thus it probably shouldn't have left Early Access), with the devs apparently responsive and helpful and happy to tell you about things that you won't be able to figure out (which I expect to be quite a bit), yet not willing to actually complete the product. Some of the other reviewers like this system, but I personally cannot conceive recommending this any time soon unless you expect your games to come with a support system and have that fact reflected in the price; after all, I prefer playing a finished game in the first place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024957270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1609196667}
review:
It's a small and fun game.
Easy to "break". 

As it stands at the moment, it does provide some fun, like cult game that you feel the urge to explore and beat in a sustainable way. But I would not recommend it mostly due to:
- bad user interface when you want to manage a full solar system
- very very clunky and with constant shakes when playing the game at full speed
- broken game mechanics: at my third play, I just focused on creating a sustainable route between Earth and Moon and exploited it for a lot of profit, ignoring most of the system. Then I ventured out with the same profile, and focused on researching: massive cargo hauls, drone automation.

Once you hit drone automation, the game is done for. 
Farm for level 2, leaving the game while you go watch a movie. 
Upgrade research stations, so you can get hub level 3
Make one hub level 3, so that Earth is not sending drones to the entire system. 
Infinite profits, I don't even bother planning routes send I got drones between earth and moon. 
Economically conquering the game is now just a matter of time, not even a challenge.


In short, interface and user experience need quite a it of work, it's very bad to manage a complex number of routes.
Game mechanics make it too easy to win, if you focused your path on 1) long haul to enable drone automation, and 2) focus on hub level 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073875274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4808, 'last_played': 1640209146}
review:
This will be a bit of a long one. But I can't help it.
On the surface I absolutely love everything about this game. I have turned back to it many times trying to make it work. But it just feels like the fundamentals of the gameplay is not working quite right with what the game is trying to be. And I always end up leaving a bit unsatisfied.
The game is about humanity colonizing the solar system and later going beyond. That's what got me real exited about the game. But that is not what you are doing. You are there to make money. On the surface this is great.
But the problem is that the best ways to make money is not at all natural and feels more like exploiting game mechanics. By not exploiting the game you will spend centuries waiting before you have enough money to leave the system.

To take an example. You need raw resources to make consumer goods. But if you do the sensible thing of building consumer goods factories on the planets that needs them the most. You earn nothing at all. You don't earn money by producing consumer goods. Only by shipping them to the planet. By producing them on site you are giving them away for free.
The best way to earn money on consumer goods. Is to first have a planet mine raw resources, Then ship that to a planet with almost no population but loads of factories, then ship that again to the planets that actually need them. For every stop you add you get to make a profit.

Consumer goods is one thing but the problem becomes more apparent when you start producing a certain resource that needs loads of water, and the last thing you want to do is to produce that thing on any planet that has access to water. The factories will keep on running even if the entire population is about to die of thirst. And that means they are willing to pay a hefty premium for any water shipments.
So in the end by the time you are ready to travel interstellar. The entire solar system is a giant mess where dozens of resources are being shipped to outlandish locations anywhere in the system. Just to maximize the number of stops where you get to take a profit.

I would give it a pass if I could. But I have to like or dislike it. So I guess it will be a like. I did enjoy the majority of time playing it. Before the problems of the mechanics became too apparent. But I doubt I will give the game another try again. It keeps improving every time I come back but the fundamentals stay the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010533414', 'num_games_owned': 1198, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2049, 'last_played': 1589219176}
review:
While the idea of the game is interesting, and is similar to what other transportation tycoon games like OpenTTD offer, Interstellar Transport Company unfortunately suffers from very poor user interaction and severe lack of quality of life features. Coming back to it after it's been released for a year, it is still held back by the same issues.

Just to name a pair:
1) You are playing as a logistics company, but you do not have access to ANY sort of logistics data. Some sort of cargo throughput information? Nope. Maybe the approximate time it would take to make a trip for the ship? Also nope. Current or average range between stops? Once again, no. Required fuel? No way to find out either. And according to the developer, this is actually intended.

2) To find out which industries you need to build (identify bottlenecks), you have to know how much your planets are producing. The game still offers no way of getting the combined output or consumption of your planets in any form. Want to see what the bottleneck in your system with 15 colonies is? Have fun adding up all 15 of those manually.

3) No way to set complex logic for your trade stops. Want to make a route of several passenger stops, but don't have any passengers for some of them? Too bad, you're still flying there with no purpose. Same goes for cargo runs - there's no way to stop your ships from going on multi-stop routes with no cargo without making a separate route.

Because of this, trying to use trade routes in any form later in the game becomes a slog - the game simply doesn't provide any useful tools or information, some of which are critical.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026140328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1583930543}
review:
Ich bin nicht der Ansicht, dass das Spiel fertig ist. Schon angefangen mit der deutschen Übersetzung gibt es gleich zu Beginn oft noch englische Texte. Natürlich verstehe ich sie, aber wenn das Spiel als deutsch gekennzeichnet ist, sollte es auch komplett sein. Im frühen Zugang ist das in Ordnung, wenn das Spiel fertig ist jedoch nicht. Und wenn Merkur 'Quecksilber' heißt - direkt im Startsystem, zeigts ja den Stand der Übersetzung an.

Die Grafik ist funktionell, die Leistungsanforderung dafür aber viel zu hoch.

Die meisten Fenster enthalten eher Text und Zahlen, nur wenig Bilder. Auch das gefällt mir weniger, macht den Einstieg lieblos. Es mag sein, dass das Spiel später beim richtigen Spielen mehr Spaß macht, allerdings wird es nie was fürs Auge werden, sondern nur was fürs steigende Bankkonto.

Insgesamt finde ich Spiel und Steuerung auch recht unintuitiv. Entweder hat der Entwickler noch nicht viele derartiger Spiele selbst gespielt, oder es mangelt an der Umsetzung. Ein Spiel dieser Art braucht auch keine einzelnen Tutorials, ein einfacher Haken beim erstellen eines neuen Spieles sollte genügen und dann bekommt man alles am Anfang erklärt.
Aber schon an der Stelle scheitert der Entwickler leider.

Es geht noch weiter, wie auch mit dem Forschen, man bekommt lauter Schiffe beim Kauf angezeigt, die man eigentlich noch nicht kennen kann, weil sie erst erforscht werden müssen. Und so weiter und so weiter.

Ich gebe es wieder zurück, denn ich wollte ein fertiges Spiel, keinen frühen Zugang.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014296958', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1585294718}
review:
[b]I'm not recommending Interstellar Transport Company in it's current state. If the developers continue to work and improve the game I will edit my review depending on the changes.[/b]

The game is not bad. But it's not great either. If this was an early access game I wouldn't complain or not recommend against this game, but it is not right to have this game in the Steam store as a fully release title.

What I enjoy most about space games is the atmosphere and this game made me hate space. Pirate attacks will happen with extremely annoying sounds every 30 seconds (granted, this is on max game speed) and the music/soundtrack in the game is horrible. The sound "engineer" of this game should NOT be allowed to be within 100 ft of any instrument ever again for the sake of humanity. I had to play this game with the sound turned off because it is so extremely bad and annoying to listen to.

The UI feels very old, like a 2010 game at best. It's a very clumsy and messy, basic UI that reminded me of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1510/Uplink/]Uplink[/url], a 2006 game that I enjoyed a lot.. In 2006. This game feels like it's from the same era. Maybe it was actually made in 2006 and just never release until now, that would explain a lot.
For the names in the game it's obvious they are not creative "Doeing", "Spacebus".. it's just cringy, it's a fantasy sci-fi space game, just make up something yourself.

Everything about the developer and the studio in general just feels like a clumsy project thrown together a lot faster than they actually try to make you believe. Their website is extremely basic and the pictures show the file names like pretty_spaceport, pretty_ships_orbiting etc. Nothing horrible per se, just messy and not refined, like everything else they do. Also, on their website they boast having a 85% positive review score (during early access).. when actually it's 75% today. Still a good score, but misleading.

Same goes for their tutorial. There is a fairly basic but decent "window with text" tutorial in the game but when you launch the game you get the option to see a 30 minute video tutorial on youtube, nothing wrong with that I thought. Until I actually watched the tutorial.. it just feels like the dev was forced to make the tutorial against his will and he wanted to spend as little time and effort as possible on it. There are multiple times he misspoke and he just starts from the beginning of the sentence like nothing happened. Someone who cares would at least edit out those mistakes. There are a few times he mentions "I think this/that" in his tutorial, which is strange for someone who made the game himself not being sure about the content. 

To conclude, I'm not saying it's a bad game but it could be so much better if they didn't release this as a completed game and would keep improving it. At the time of writing the last change/update to the game was on the 4th of December 2019, 66 days ago, so I don't think the developers are still actively working on the game or caring too much about the future of it. But I hope they prove me wrong. 

5/10

review:

-Графика. Графики как таковой нет. Есть просто круглые условные планеты. Корабли похожи на что yгодно -  на сапоги, зажигалки, брелки для ключей но только не на корабли.
-Спецификация кораблей. Она отсутствует. На любой корабль вы можете повесить что yгодно как контейнеры для руды, так и пассажирские места, баки для жидкостей. Что в принципе не логично. И сделать транспортную компанию специализирующуюся на чем то конкретно не возможно. Все возят всё и на всём! Это бред!
-Названия кораблей. У авторов совсем все плохо с фантазией. Впечатление что названия сгенерированны каким то генератором имен. В конце концов могли бы просто скомуниздить названия в космосимуляторах разных, где авторы на это потратили хотя бы несколько часов и включили фантазию.
-Оптимизация. Нет. В эту игру её не завезли. Она начинает лагать уже при колонизации 4ой планеты. И это на игровом ноуте MSI 2016-ого года.
-Разнообразие ресурсов. ?? Неа. Тут полный примитив и однообразие.
-Музыка. Она взята то ли из тетриса 1992 года, то ли из Цивилизации 3. 8 или 16 бит, я точно не знаю. Из yшей идёт кровь. Поэтому её надо отключать как и русский язык. Во многих играх при прочих косяках, недоработках, унынии картинки, иногда музыка решает и делает атмосферу в игре неповторимой. Но тут авторы решили похоронить свой проект окончательно.

author: {'steamid': '76561198838137134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6152, 'last_played': 1708477764}
review:
Overall this is a great tycoon game and I recommend it. It is fun and different than most.

That said, there are several issues that need to be fixed or improved in order to really make it better:

- Biggest problem is performance, for me (Linux) open any of the filter windows (ships, starports) causes the game to lag horribly. It seems to help if you minimize the use of drones but it is still bad.

- UI for managing ships is OK, but could use some love to manage large numbers of ships. Especially with the first problem.

- It would be cool if you could pay to send a generation ship to fill out a colony's development (would be a late game tech, $25-$50M or so) or if you could pay to "advertise" a colony to temporarily get more colonists. Or other "pay for single-use" techs like that.

- More complex tech chains would be nice to help with the late game, where things get a bit flat. Overall the game plateaus really quickly after you get out of your home system. More rare resources, more planet-unique buildings, etc.

- The research tree probably needs rebalancing. The first few techs are critical and take a long time. After that you get a ton of research points and finish the rest quickly. I would say overall the points needed for later techs should be increased, but maybe should have power improved accordingly.

- It would be good if you could customize what resources drones will send, or where they will send them to. Sometimes for example they will send tons of raw resources and ignore more important ones. I think they maximize for profit but that is not always what you want.

- The help should be filled out more. In particular it is not obvious to me what factors increase/decrease numbers of colonists and it is not clear if, for example, you deliver colonists between hubs, if the drones will send colonists to outlying colonies.

Again, overall really fun, just has a few rough edges.

review:
I enjoyed the challenge of the first playthrough, and discovering all of the hidden traps that can kill you.

Then I enjoyed solely responsible, calculating the appropriate ratios over time necessary to get all of the home planets to 100 development

Then I enjoyed the high score system, re-playing the first year over and over to get the highest fares - fuel i could, then repeating that strategy for 10 yrs to get high scores.

The challenge of getting a 100 development planet in another star system was fun... you really have to pump out boat loads of dilithium, and then put 2 refineries on every home planet, just to get enough fuel to sustain your home away from home... it really gives you the insentive to grow your home world beyond just 'profitable'...
I enjoyed playing thru each of the other game types for 10 years just to set high scores and get a feel for how the modes work.

60 hours of fun is plenty for the price point, and I consider this game well worth the money and worth recommending. Of course I'd selfishly love if the game could give me 9000 hours of fun... :) cya.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993240784', 'num_games_owned': 1435, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1563001430}
review:
[h1]Начиная свой бизнес…[/h1]
 
Слишком часто из уст разработчиков мы слышим заманчивые обещания интересных механик, продвинутого управления бизнесом и прочих вкусностей, которые могут разнообразить и улучшить геймплей игры.
 
На деле же получаем поверхностные возможности, не дающие желаемого количества удовольствия от процесса. Как же себя покажет  Interstellar Transport Company, в которой нам обещают реалистичный бизнес менеджмент - давайте разберемся.
 
[h1]Войны цифр![/h1]
 
Нам предлагают взять под свое управление межпланетную транспортную компанию и схлестнуться в борьбе с другими фирмами за доминирование на рынке поставок товаров.

Чтобы достигнуть цели придется сильно постараться!
 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1802137694
Сессия в Interstellar Transport Company начинается в стартовой солнечной системе, где мы и будем формировать свой основной капитал. Первые шаги всегда одинаковые: определяемся, что будем поставлять, откуда и куда. Делается это с помощью специального меню для создания маршрутов, в котором определяются тип груза и точки погрузки/разгрузки, но существуют некоторые ограничения.
 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1802138575
Во-первых, выбирая транспортный корабль или одноразовую ракету-носитель, придется учитывать объемы максимально перевозимого груза, ведь вместимость грузового отсека не бесконечна. Во-вторых, товары разделены по группам по 1, 2 и 3 наименования в каждой, поэтому, к примеру, нельзя будет набрать еду в место, предназначенное  под воду.

В-третьих, выполнять грузоперевозки с доходом в одну сторону – невыгодно и долго.
Каждая планета или спутник обладает своим набором параметров, определяющих, что вообще там можно добывать и насколько эффективно. Наиболее “сочные” космические тела быстро становятся новыми колониями, требующими пристального внимания и иногда поставок необходимого за копейки. Дабы работать не в убыток, игрой предусмотрена система субсидий, когда за наиболее остро необходимые товары вам будут платить больше обычного.

Но не только лишь грамотным построением маршрутов и ценностью перевозимых товаров определяется успех, ведь без должной инфраструктуры также не обойтись. Прежде всего, вашим кораблям нужно где-то приземляться для погрузки/выгрузки товаров, поэтому придется позаботиться об аренде дока, но конкуренты не дремлют. Количество мест ограничено развитостью космического порта, а перекупить у оппонента док не получится. Впрочем, можно вложить деньги в развитие космопорта, тем самым расширив количество свободного пространства.
 
Наземная инфраструктура тоже важна. Стоит позаботиться об оборудовании ремонтных ангаров, ведь все грузовые посудины требуют постоянного обслуживания, а застрять посреди космоса с поломкой, значит понести серьезные убытки. Не менее полезны системы шаттлов, ускоряющие погрузку/разгрузку пристыкованных кораблей.
 
Несколько позже появится возможность субсидирования колоний. Прежде всего, постройкой желаемых добывающих и производственных предприятий.  Скажем, на одной из планет слишком много сырья – постройте на соседней фабрику по производству потребительских товаров и вуаля, у вас новый рынок сбыта сырья! Таким образом можно искусственно создавать новые выгодные маршруты для поставок.
 
[h1]Тонкости бизнеса[/h1]
 
В Interstellar Transport Company множество показателей, без учета которых можно быстро сесть в лужу, в частности,  уровень безопасности, определяющий концентрацию военных патрулей, охраняющих транспортные фирмы от пиратов, которые так и норовят лишить корабли их товаров. Уровень безопасности повышается за счет специальных зданий, которые требуют поставок вооружения, которое еще надо где-то производить.
 
Также каждая планета относится к вашей компании по-разному. Показатель этот зависит от количества поставляемых товаров, наличия локального офиса и состояния планеты в целом.
 
И, конечно же, если хотите выжить своих конкурентов с рынка, будьте готовы к тому, что придется учитывать потребности колоний, ибо у них постоянно что-то случается. Нехватка еды приведет к голоду, стихийное бедствие потребует срочной поставки разнообразных товаров. Игнорирование их потребностей приведет к банальному вымиранию колонии, впрочем, печалиться не стоит, ведь довольно скоро очередной колониальный корабль завезет новую порцию жертв … эээ … в смысле, потребителей.
 
[h1]Прогресс не стоит на месте[/h1]
 
Ощущение прогрессирования по игре не выражается лишь в толщине кошелька, но и подкрепляется системой исследований. Постройка на планетах научных станций приведет к накоплению специальных очков, за которые производится покупка улучшений: новых кораблей, возможности межзвездных путешествий и самого страшного оружия транспортной коммерции на данный момент – дронов. Древо технологий достаточно прямолинейно, количество же технологий скудно.

 
[h1]Красив ли космос?[/h1]
 
Не в данном случае. Графическое исполнение игры очень простое, большую часть времени вы будете лицезреть снующие по карте разноцветные метки транспортных кораблей, а также большой ассортимент графиков и цифр.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1802137051
Звуковое сопровождение вполне приемлемое, хотя не отличается каким-либо разнообразием или уникальным антуражем.
 
[h1]Проблемные моменты[/h1]
 
Interstellar Transport Company обещает нам реалистичный бизнес-менеджмент, и в целом справляется с этой задачей, однако некоторые недоработки все же  имеются.
 
Во-первых, субсидирование колонии путем постройки добывающих и производственных предприятий само по себе не дает никакого дохода. Да, вы создаете новый рынок сбыта или источник товаров для поставки, но скажите мне, какая компания в здравом уме «бесплатно» построит кому-то предприятие?
 
Во-вторых, хромающий баланс. На текущий момент самым лучшим способом транспортировки и получения колоссального дохода выступают дроны. Спешное прогрессирование и исследование 3 тира дронов приведет к превращению локальной звездной системы в паутину, из которой очень быстро будут вытеснены все оппоненты. Забудьте про межзвездные перелеты, когда есть маленькие роботы, летающие со скоростью света и не требующие ремонта.

В-третьих, скучное древо технологий. Честно говоря, оно настолько не разнообразно и прямолинейно, что возникает вопрос о целесообразности его существования.
 
В-четвертых, нехватка глубины некоторых механик. Предположим, по вашему недосмотру вымерла колония, что же будет? А ничего – прилетят новые поселенцы, и репутация у вас с ними будет отличная. Откровенно говоря, не хватает некой общей репутации, которая динамически воздействовала бы на все колонии сразу, а для того, чтобы игра не вынуждала поставлять все и всем, требовалось бы сначала заключать с колониями договора на поставку.
 
[h1]Итог[/h1]
 
[b]Плюсы:[/b]
+ Неплохая система бизнес-менеджмента.
+ Гибкий инструмент построения маршрутов поставки.
+ Большое разнообразие средств транспортировки со своими плюсами и минусами.
+ Хороший выбор сложности, позволяющий как научиться, так и столкнуться с испытаниями.
+ Мультиплеер.
 
[b]Минусы:[/b]
- Скучное древо технологий.
- Некоторым механикам не хватает глубины проработки.
- Баланс, в частности, дроны, которые превращают вторую половину игры в наблюдение за смертью конкурентов.
 
Interstellar Transport Company – хорошая игра про менеджмент с большим количеством цифр и графиков, но в которой хотелось бы увидеть еще больше механик и больше возможностей.
 
Моя оценка: 7 из 10. Достойная игра, заслуживающая внимания, тем более, в ней есть мультиплеер.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960812573', 'num_games_owned': 226, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1679423241}
review:
I want to recommend this game. The first few hours were fun. Micro some ships here, a route there... But once you reached the stage where you get intrasystem drones, all routes become irrelevant and drones handle everything on their own. Interstellar travel is not worth it, since you barely make profit, and that with all tech unlocked and all ships available. At least in my experience.  I got all (ten) achievements in about 10 hours, which could have been faster if I hadn't ballsed up my first game. In the second game I got the (final) 100.000.000 casherino achievement by waiting for my drones to do it for me. I didn't own a single ship once I had 2 or maybe 3 level 3 drone hubs (they cover the entire solar system).

The concept of the game is great. But it feels unfinished. As if it was still in early access, which I usually avoid like alpha or beta versions, or the plague.

For a release title, this game lacks content. The tech tree is sparse, so is the roster of ship types. And the UI needs work, I'll leave it at that. I wish there was Steam Workshop support, because all you nerds usually fix games like this. Giggity.

I played 10 hours, and at least 5 of them I watched Netflix and waited for drones to do drone stuff. I spent roughly 17€ during the summer sale, and I feel like I overpaid. I want to recommend, but I can't. 

To be continued...

author: {'steamid': '76561198049532860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1561939292}
review:
I got this game as it was on sale, and overall it was definitely worth the money.

Firstly, one must counter the learning curve that comes with this game. In my first run, it was the sheer idea of supply and demand I had to overcome, and inevitably I fell behind the other two ai companies immediately. In my second run, it was the idea of economic bubbles, and how to save enough capital to avoid spiraling after a bubble bursts. I focused and still do focus on the raw materials to consumer goods trade, and in my second run I burst the bubble by no longer needing raw materials on the home planet, and then not having enough capital to reinvest elsewhere. On my third run, although I ran into the issue early game of not focusing on drones or quantity of ships, I managed to late game bankrupt the other companies, establish multiple artificial raw material bubbles, and end with a 50 year total of around 500 million net worth, which positioned me at #14 on the leaderboard (which I assume is for the system of which I started, this is something I hope can be expanded on via tooltips.) Here is the link to that third run 50 year screenshots: https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/522930950452150282/595041289439936680/unknown.png

Though, with this, I did end up getting all the achievements, and since the game has many updates to come, I simply ran out of things to do.

If you believe 10-20 hours of gameplay as a base is good for the price, then get the game. If you get mentally hooked on these games and want to keep playing more and more, DEFINITELY buy it. If you don't think the base is worth the price, either wait for more updates before buying or move on.

I am having a lot of fun with this game. The theme reminds me of the setting for many of the science fiction stories I've enjoyed. I love where it starts as well, right at the beginning of interstellar travel. Star systems can be built from barren rocks into a thriving web of colonies. This game sets itself apart from other space colonization games in that the focus is almost entirely on shipping and transportation. It is an interesting limitation that makes you change the way you approach problems. 

I am eagerly looking forward to developments and any dlc that expands on what is already a fun game.

review:
great game until you leave the solar system. thats when you start to really see how blatantly obvious this game just isnt finished. i have over 20 hours in the game but believe me when i say, a vast majority of that is me sitting around watching Twitch or Netflix just to pass the time. 

the game needs to be rebalanced to speed things along and more things need to happen. right now theres no events that require you to interact with them in any way at all in order to keep you engaged with the game. the money generation is so slow, it just kills any enjoyment of you wanting to expand to different solar systems. one of the achievements says to reach $100,000,000. i can barely reach $5,000,000 without sitting around DOING NOTHING waiting for hours. in order to make more money, you need to replace your older ships with bigger ones but in order to do that, you need to save up. if your in the late game with upwards of 15 ships per route going from earth to another planet and back, thats hours of just sitting around waiting. i hope you can catch a theme here. you do nothing but sit around waiting for a number counter to get bigger.

i struggle trying to figure out if this game was designed to be fun or just something to waste time on and i honestly cant say i had fun. if this is what the devs call a finished product, i cant willingly support them. its a shame too because this game had so much potential. i might go back to it in another year and see if anything has been added to it. otherwise, its a clear miss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059371989', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1575472999}
review:
This game went live from early access as unfinished; it has bugs and design issues, but more so there's no end game content built in. Furthermore if you really try to play and expand your trading empire just for the heck of it, by trying to conquer interstellar systems, performance issues kick in and the game starts lagging. Even with a high end gaming setup.

I really liked the early game. This game does have potential. but it's still at early stage of development. Towards mid and end game, it all starts to become a micro management hell with the ships and shipping lanes. Personally I experienced bad UI bug issues, which forced me to constantly restart game every time I wanted to use the dropdown menu to change shipping routes of ships (the menu becomes transparent and always on, so you can't see what route you'd choose).

Research options quickly top out while you're still at the starting home Earth system, with the first maxed research stations you can build. You don't really get to use any of the intermediary ship types; they expire before you can buy them. Some tuning required here.

Once interstellar colonies open up, Earth starts to be so populated, that it requires a special energy generating resource "Stellarium" to function. Stellarium can only be found in interstellar systems. But not having it available at Earth or other systems which become highly populated, causes their development status drop from 100% to 0%. That means that in mid-end game when Earth becomes populated, and it doesn't have enough of this Stellarium, all the production of the planet falls to zero. There's no middle ground, you just lose all the productions, of which many other of your systems might depend on.

Now, when the Stellarium crisis happened with my game, I was going to maybe just call it quits. But then tried to get a supply running from the closest interstellar system with a Stellarium source. I did get it running, in the end. However, the Stellarium requirement to keep Earth running is currently so huge, that my supply route from that interstellar planet to Earth is now 203 ships. And pretty much all of those are the last researched ship type Cochin Saagar, which costs $3.3mil to buy. That ship has 205 cargo bays to ferry Stellarim and take time to travel through the light years, while Earth alone has a ~500 deficit at population of 10bil. And same for other highly populated planets.

Once you get the Stellarium shipping set up with about 200 ships, and then start to use your profits to expand into other interstellar systems just for the heck of it, the game starts lagging badly at around 400 ships total.

All the resource production in the game is currently unbalanced. Meaning that one source and factory is usually enough to produce ridiculous amounts of resources, enough for the whole system. Regardless of the resource availability percentage assigned to each planetoid. You just need one source per star system to distribute from, and can disregard the rest (besides food/water), even if the availability % is low. You'll end up with ridiculous stockpiles of millions of resources that can't be used. Food and water balance seems ok to me, and you'd need to hunt down planetoids rich in either to supply an interstellar system much later on (if the gameplay ever went that far).

In my game there's no positive luxury resource production. Earth and one other planetoid in all the systems having a positive value for Luxuries Availability %, however Earth consumes about 5 times more than in can produce. Which means no luxuries anywhere after early game. And one of the game features Weaponry requires luxuries to produce. Although I haven't really noticed any adverse effects of any place not having a supply of weaponry. I did see some messages skip by at bottom of screen, about piracy or something, but didn't catch it.

Late in my game I noticed it's easy to 'cheat' for much more money, by sponsoring multiple robotics factories on a planet. Which use Machinery and Consumer Goods as resource. Consumer Goods especially is very easy to generate in abundance by most planets. So you'll just have a drone distribution hangar on a planetoid with Consumer Goods in the same system as the planetoid with multile robotics factories, and you keep racking up crazy revenue for delivering Consumer Goods at high cost for the robotics factory. Which in turn just churns up robotics into a gicantic stockpile, never to be used. This is one fault of a trading game; that you can get infinitely paid well to produce something that'll never get used. Where does that capital come from?

After all this rant, like I said in beginning I DID enjoy playing this game. And don't think it a bad investment for the asking price. But there's a lot of development work to be done still, to call this a finished game.

For example there is no end game yet. You just finish all the research early on, and then fight to keep Earth running after they decide they'll need Stellarium to keep it going. Then you can expand to other interstellar systems, to have something to do. But this colonizing for the principle, and keeping big planets running just to keep the species alive regardless of profit, is not that much in region of running just a trading company for profit.

[h1] 宇宙是一个每分钟旋转一万次的巨大飞轮。人只是叮在它上面的一只头晕目眩的小虫[/h1]


[h1] 前言[/h1]
《星际运输公司》（Interstellar Transportation Company）是一款以宇宙为舞台的Sci-Fi物流企业模拟游戏游戏，玩家经营一家太空运输公司，为边际宇宙各个角落的人类提供生存必需品。玩家必须妥善管理太空飞船、运输路线、殖民地、公司金融和组织架构，击败自己的对手，本作的采用坚实的科学理论基础，利用算法生成浩瀚的银河系，打造真实而且新鲜的星路地图，每次游戏都绝不相同。

[h1] 游戏体验和感想[/h1]
 [*游戏设立在2050的太空，人类文明超高度自由，我们需要在每个恒星和每个行星之间建立基站和规划路线购买太空船进行物资运输并且在星球上建立建筑物，星球上需要各种各样的建筑，可以看到食物，水，矿物，稀有资源和人口等等，你需要吸引更多的星际游民来赚钱同时和对手公司竞争击垮他！多人模式BUG比较多，不太完善所以主要对抗AI有快速竞赛和自定义游戏两种模式。游戏除了界面中文游戏里几乎没有中文仅有的一些中文也像乱码似的，所以教学难懂英语不太好的玩家需要全程手持谷歌翻译，也称得上比较硬核了。
 [*每天上课和晚上睡觉，总是幻想着无穷无尽的宇宙感觉感觉整个人都飘到天空里遨游，如果人在太空里不会因为真空被压强压到爆炸也不会憋死，那我们就可以飘在太空里想去那就去那，那才是真正的环游世界。虽然有些中只制作了一个类似于银河系大小并且建模质量较为简陋，但也不影响你尝试着在浩瀚无垠的太空体验到星际文明。如果真的要做出整个宇宙我觉得还是不太可能吧，比较宇宙是无限大的

[h1] 优缺点以推荐人群[/h1]

[b] 优点[/b]
[*]玩法有趣，有挑战性，数值严禁
[*]宇宙宏大内容比较多

[b] 缺点[/b]
[*]除了界面中文基本没有中文很难上手
[*]优化较差内存负载太大（导致我卡死过）
[*]操作工序繁多浪费时间

[b] 推荐人群[/b]
喜欢模拟经营管理类喜欢太空星际类游戏的玩家可以尝试，价格过高

author: {'steamid': '76561198004282046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1574804550}
review:
Game is nothing like Stellaris, but it has design problems like Stellaris did at launch.

I think this game is a great effort, and I didnt experience bugs, but quality is lacking in areas besides production values.

As someone who wanted to like this game, I can't recommend it until the underlying design itself receives more polish.  The choice to use a full 3d map doesn't really seem to have paid off well.  Too many things are in the game that don't improve it, including UI buttons, mechanics, ships, technologies, etc.

Too many gameplay mechanics do not add to the experience, I believe these are things that seemed like good ideas but as currently implemented they detract from some combination of fun or intuitive-ness of the rules.  Not enough tools to deal with organizational challenges.  And the UI definitely has issues, a large amount of real estate sometimes is claimed to display very little information (though some windows are better designed than others)

I played on a harder difficulty and on my second game, I researched the first ship upgrade and took out a loan to buy 2, the AI players were no longer competitive after that (not that I would have understood why I was being out-competed with the current design) and I blew through a surprising amount of the tech tree with only two not-upgraded research stations.

This is a game about interstellar expansion and I felt like I had seen most things after a few of Jupiter's moons were colonized.  Like Stellaris it seems like this game launched without a vision for how the player would proceed through to the endgame.

review:
Yes, this is Transport Tycoon in Space. (somebody probably wrote that already...)
Yes, the UI is not intuitive (right click to resize), and takes some time to get used to. I don't mind though.
Yes, in general it takes some time to learn the game, but that is pretty normal with any Strategy Game, and I prefer that over any tight hand-holding mechanics. 
Yes, there is an Options Menu for Sound, Graphics, Key Binding and Language. Basic, but I haven't missed anything so far.

Did I miss anything?
Information about fuel prices, maybe. Would be nice to have sometimes, although for shorter trips it's not relevant.
A way to get rid of my Google Sheets and Paper, but i guess i would miss those more. After all what is left for you to do, when the game does all the calculations for you ;-)

Great Game for an Indie title at that price. So far I have spend 20 hours in game, that's 1 Euro per hour. And I will add some more hours to that counter for sure. Pretty good value if you ask me. 

tl,dr:
If you are not already convinced by "Transport Tycoon in Space", then I don't know what else I can tell you...
7 out of 5 gold pressed latinum

author: {'steamid': '76561198008501262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1765, 'last_played': 1560203185}
review:
TL:DR buy this game if you like hard games about logistics and don't care much about graphics.

1.01B Edits: These changes added about 2.5 hours more total play interest for me. 

This game got off to a rough start with me, so this review will, too, but there's good stuff at the end. The tutorials, while on point as far as they go, don't seem complete, and there doesn't seem to be a way to reset them like you can with Stellaris or other games. There's no manual or wiki I've been able to find and so there's no "RTFM" for a newb. You get one shot at the tutorial tips, it seems, and then it's in to the deep end with you.

Also challenging is that a major technological shift occurs mid-game with no notice about it's game ending implications. At some point your planets will start demanding a resource called stellarium, and if you don't have it ready before you need it, you are essentially forced to manage the logistics of an interstellar collapse as your home worlds starve for lack of it whereas just a few years ago they were fine without it. Since I saw no messages about this change and it wasn't a consequence of my research, this particular technological bridge required me three restarts to figure out what the hell had happened and how to deal with it.

Technically, this game puts a far greater load on your graphics card and its memory than the graphics really warrant. They're not that impressive but still overheated my NVIDIA 1080 whereas battlefield V, ARMAIII, and Stellaris do not. I think they need streamlining of their resource demand, but truly, if you're spending your time watching the pretty spaceships fly by, you're doing it wrong anyway. I turned my graphics down to ultra low and that makes the game time elapse a lot faster without heating up my GPU to 82 degrees.

Once you jump that stellarium technological hurdle there doesn't seem to be much to do rather than farm out all the remaining stellarium in your galaxy and watching your civilization starve at a much later date. The tech tree stops early and there isn't a lot to do except more of the same that got you that far.

That being said, the fact that this is a hard game about logistics, something that most games ignore in the pursuit of bigger explosions and bustier heroines, and the fact that it challenges me is part of its charm. Many other games go to easy on me, but not this one: it forces me to think ahead and redo rather than get by with lazy or ignorant decision making. I feel sharper for having played it, and I have spent about 30 hours on it so far and will enjoy playing more once they've expanded the tech tree and added more late game. 

I've paid a lot more money for games I've played a lot less, and I think 20-25 is about the price point that's right as it stands. The developers are responsive, but they would do themselves a service by supplying good documentation or a guide for the game so they don't have to spend developer time explaining its mechanics over and over.

review:
I didn't want to write this review.

Pros:

Good Business Simulation
Overall Interesting

Cons:

UI
Tutorial Pop-Ups
Learning Curve


-----======------

The UI is terrible, you get to a point while playing the game where it is super important to pay attention to supply/demand and prices. The UI is either too small and/or doesn't get the right information to the player. It's just clunky and terribly designed. The tooltips don't help much either, other than give broad information.

Overall it seems like a good game, but the AI makes it feel unbearable to play for more than a hour. Also the tech tree feels incomplete or an afterthought. There should be more options, more ships, modifications to stats, upgrades. Also the prices for tech are way too far apart, I find myself just waiting and waiting to get enough points before I upgrade one of my routes to a new ship class.

The tutorial pop-up windows reminded me of the days that I had "won a free iPad just click here" ads and would find myself just clicking furiously to close the windows thinking they contained mostly useless information. Some times they were helpful, but they did contain useless information some times or would pop-up more than once for the same subject. I also couldn't figure out how to move ships from one route to a different route, only the "upgrade option" which bought a new ship and sold the old one. May be that information was in one of those pop-up's I clicked through, but it was not even remotely obvious in the UI either.

review:
J'y ai peu joué pour l'instant (1h environ). De ce que j'ai vu, le jeu a l'air assez sympa, d'où l'avis positif.

Par contre, dire que le jeu est traduit en français, c'est une vaste plaisanterie. Et de mauvais goût.

Beaucoup de choses sont encore en anglais, comme par exemple le tuto et finalement beaucoup de descriptions. Mon niveau en anglais étant ce qu'il est (pathétique donc), j'ai donc un peu de mal avec pas mal de choses qui seraient surement plus claires autrement. J'ajouterais aussi que pour déclarer un jeu traduit dans une langue, il y a deux conditions : la première c'est que TOUT soit traduit (on en est loin) ET que la traduction ne sorte pas de google translate (ce qui est le cas ici).

Bref, si vous êtes allergique aux jeux de gestion en anglais (comme moi), je ne le recommande pas. Pour ceux que ça ne dérange pas, je pense que le jeu est assez cool. C'est typiquement dans ce genre de cas que j'aimerais pouvoir laisser un avis neutre. Le jeu est paru il y a moins d'un mois donc pour l'instant je resterais indulgent.

J'arrête ce jeu pour l'instant, mais j'espère pouvoir y revenir quand il sera enfin traduit (en suivant la description de ce qu'est une traduction qui est fournie plus haut).

review:
This is a great logistics simulator for the colonization of the solar system and beyond!

As a great fan of Raylroad Tycoon 3's economy simulation, I think this is a worthy successor, and unprecedented in its sheer scale of simulation. Consider that each and every unit of each type of good exists somewhere, whether as in the cargohold of one of thousands of ships on the move, or in an aggregate of each city's (planet/moon) stockpile.

Start from one-way supply rockets (Saturn 5 equivalents), all the way into warp-capable transport shuttles (think Fifth Element). In the in-between help the Solar System grow from humble beginnings into an interstellar trade empire, all while competing against AI corporations (or players, but I have not tried that yet).

Think Offworld Trade Company in a much-MUCH larger scale.

I bought the game last night after watching some youtube videos, and suddenly it was 4 am - I traveled 5 hours into the future. No, I wasn't abducted by aliens, I just lost myself in immersion with the game.

I hope the devs continue to add more content to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998490477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 13431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7700, 'last_played': 1656135144}
review:
What a nice transport tycoon game! Learning curve is a bit steep, but not too much. Youtube has some helpful videos to help you to get started or decide, if this game is for you.

The game is set in the future, where humanity is starting to colonize planets and moons in the star system and eventually other star systems. Your job is to make profit by providing colonies resources, which help them develop and grow. That is done by setting up routes between planets and moons, buying ships to routes and setting up cargo holds to ships, pretty much in this order. As the colonies develop, their needs change: Colonies need no more food, if they can grow it themselves, or machinery to help to develop planet, if it is already fully developed. However, consumer goods and other resources are then needed.

I saw some youtuber play this a couple years ago, it looked fascinating. I bought it, played it, found it a bit unpolished, but developer was active. A couple weeks ago I tried it again, and it has been improved a lot. I am still figuring out things, like optimal ways to transport cargo. There are still some unpolished things, but developer is also still active.

Overall, the game is fascinating and playable. If you like transport games and space games, worth to check.

review:
LATEST UPDATE: Dev is very responsive and claims the fix to this will be available in the next patch!  I just tested the pre-release and all these issues are now fixed.


!!!!!!!HURRAY!!!!!!!!



So you can safely ignore all the blather below.  Just buy the game already!



----OLDER----
NOTE: At the moment of this writing, the dev seems to be scrambling to understand the issues described here - so it seems like a fun time to promote this game, as all the drama seems to be at its peak. :)

-----Original post (please see updates as this is deprecated, but funny) ----




An unenthusiastic thumbs up.

The UI is not independent of screen resolution.  People have been beheaded in other countries for writing a UI like this.  It's really quite bad.

You see this programmer from Renaissance times?  She wrote a bad UI too.  Okay?
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1234096904

The UI problem in Interstellar Transport Company has 2 (clunky, unintuitive) workarounds, so I'm probably over-reacting.  But as long as it's like this - it will nag at me and eventually I'll just uninstall out of sheer contempt.  For $25 a customer should expect a better game-play experience than this.  There's this first moment of realization, when a screen pops up and it's TINY, and there's a feeling of "oh my god this game is shit!" which is followed by "do I need to ask for  refund?"  Yeah that feeling.  Then there's the feeling "am I going to have to adjust this screen size every time I open this window?  Are you serious?"  Try to avoid giving players these feelings, because they remember it, and they paid good money for now having something to complain about.

HINT: Most game engines have tools for making UI independent of screen resolution.  Let's take Unity, for example:
https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/HOWTO-UIMultiResolution.html

I really hope this is fixed eventually.

Otherwise - I like the game-play.  It plays very much like a railroad sim, only without the railroads.  The learning curve is not bad.  The AI opponents are apparently fixed in their starting endowments, so if you try to play with fewer funds at the beginning, prepare to never catch up to the AI opponents.

However, there's no stock market that I've found anyway - and really no sense that I can buy out or be bought out.  This is kind of nice, though hopefully the option will eventually be there to allow buyouts.  As it is, you can do you, and your opponents can do their thing, and we really don't step on each other's toes very much, other than the limited real-estate available on a planet.

The immersion is pretty good - but then again, I really like these kinds of games.  Your mileage may vary.  This is (like all other economic sims) ultimately a beautiful clicker.  Watch everything move around and wait until you have the funds and figure out how you want to spend them.

Let's hope it keeps improving.


------------- TLDR -------------

Dev is very responsive and fixed all the issues described above within a couple days.  The game is HARD.  Good luck!

review:
Great game, but needs some balancing out. This game takes a bit of time to get used to. I mean, I spent 6 hours and I only just feel like I'm getting to grips with it. The gameplay is good and interesting. It's great to set up your ships to the new planets, compare cargo sizes, compare ships. It's for people who love games like Railroad Tycoon, OpenTTD, all those sorts of things. 

However, it is a bit slow to get going and get momentum. If you don't know what you're doing, you can make mistakes and it can take a long time to get to the next stages and expend. It requires quite a lot of management and can be a bit fiddly. Also the text on the screen can be too small. Though all in all, for a new game - it has a good core, good concept and just needs some testers to give feedback to the devs.  Also at points it can get a bit boring, when you're just shipping endless food and water to a planet for it to expand and develop.

I spent 6 hours on it today and thoroughly enjoyed it though. So I think that should give a fair indication of why this could be a classic!

review:
Short answer yes with a 'but'; long answer no with an 'if'.

Right now, I'd tentatively recommend it with the usual Early Access caveat. This is a solid early access game though. There's enough gameplay to make it interesting, but the fact that it's still being fleshed out does mean some grumbly annoyances. I'd suggest you watch a YouTube video on gameplay before making the purchase. I'd normally also say to accept the flaws an Early Access game may have, but the game will literally make you do that before you start playing :)

Current Annoyances: (go read the game news to see if these have been fixed)
-AI is a bit dumb. Early on, you can monopolize the Mars port completely, but the AI will send ships anyway wasting money on ships that will orbit uselessly while you rake in the spacebucks.
-Odd tutorial. Windows opening bring up a little explanation of how to use it, but that also happens in the tutorial which can make it confusing as to what you should be doing. Since there are two sets of instructions. 
-Window behavior. The tutorial shows how you can resize windows! But it turns out you can't do all of them! But wait, there's a UI scale in the options menu--that will let you scale some things off the screen and make it hard to click a button in the lower right if there is no button. Even better still, some windows can have their scaling changed by both methods. Some windows also like to open up partway off the screen even after you reposition them.
-Zero assistance outside the tutorial and little info screens. This is the big one for me that drops this to 'tentative' rather than 'go for it'. For the window resizing, the only way to tell which method changes window size is trial and error. I've also like to be able to assign ships to other routes as better ones become available and have seen that mentioned in the discussions. [b]How[/b] to do that? Beats me, nothing in game mentions it and no button in any window mentions it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005087486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1546052761}
review:
The logic and how trading is executed is completely flawed in this game.  Things do not make sense in the grand scheme of interstellar space development.
- Earth finds a colony at Mars, Mercury, Ganymede etc.. Probably spends an exorbitant amount of resources to do that.  Then everything is left to a few transportation companies to take care of all supply? So you can lease all the ports and disable everyone from trading with this colony?? For a total of $5000 a month? Why would the founder planet or the colony planet allow this?? So you can starve them and drive up prices? That is just dumb.  Leasing a landing port should include requirements for the transportation of essential goods for the survival of the colony for a fixed (or at least minimum) profit margin.  It may not be the most profitable thing to transport food, but you should be forced to do it to retain your contract. 
- To further elaborate on Contract:  Everything is first come, first pick up, first deliver basis.  That is idiotic.  No company will ever do trade or transportation without an established contract or market. Goods should be carried through contacts, and requirement should be satisfying that contact. Ships should be purchased and allocated to honor the contract. Not on a constantly changing economic climate, or varying passenger rates, etc. Trying to deal with constant change results in insane amounts of micro management. It cannot create a fun game if the scale gets much bigger than a few planets.
- Another item that does not make sense is the transportation of food and water.  Those should be always produced at the planets easily to support a core population anyway. Why would a colony allow itself to be overpopulated when it does not make enough food for itself?  How hard is it to make water on a planet when you have the technology for "interstellar transport". Hydrogen is the most common element, Oxygen is the third most abundant. So I need to carry them in liquid form from Earth to the other planets. Right. Why don't I carry machines that make water on that planet instead?  Same with food.. You cannot grow because you're too far from an energy source?  Bring nuclear reactors to that planet and generate energy. Or bring geothermal equipment to generate energy.. Why would you carry basic things?  You should be transporting valuable raw materials that cannot be processed into refined forms, refined forms of valuable raw materials, machinery, equipment, tools, reactors, medicine, computers and luxury items etc.  Exotic foods can be an item to transport, but generic "food" not so much.  Transporting simple bare necessity items in an interstellar era and allowing entire planets suffer and millions die due to the shortage of "water" or "food" makes no sense to me.
My conclusion is that, I don't know if this game is trying to be deep or shallow.  I'm not sure if it is trying to simulate some post single planet economic model or not.  The current model is too simple and lacks any sort of depth to reflect anything even slightly futuristic. It does not even have the depth of 1994 Colonization in terms of colony building, raw materials, finished goods etc. I don't understand what the ultimate goal is either.. Remain profitable? Own items and keep on making investments? get richer and richer and richer,,, forever?
Unless there is a major overhaul of game concepts, I don't see this becoming anything enjoyable, anything with reasonable realism, or anything with a borderline acceptable economic model.  Might become a massive grind out and micromanage type of game with no real goals.  I'm not even talking about bugs and things that are not working properly either. That is a whole different topic.

review:
Je reviens faire une nouvelle évaluation du jeu puisqu'il est maintenant en version finale. Peu de chose réellement à rajouter à mon évaluation précédente faite dans l'EA.
A aujourd'hui c'est un de mes tycoons préféré. La version finale est bonne, la traduction en français s'est énormément améliorée. Les devs écoutent encore et toujours la communauté (qui est souvent très exigeantes) améliorant le jeu régulièrement, corrigeant tout rapidement. C'est un digne héritier de Transport Tycoon, mais avec une vision spatiale. Et le développement du jeu n'est pas fini, beaucoup d'amélioration vont encore venir


Première évaluation :
Le jeu est toujours en accès anticipé. mais il progresse. Je pense que le studio de dev est un petit studio. Ils écoutent la communauté et apportent les évolutions petit à petit.
Au moment ou je rédige cette évaluation, le jeu a progressé. Ils ont lissé les graphismes des menus, par exemple. Le jeu souffre encore de quelques ralentissement de temps, en temps, surtout lorsqu'on commence à avoir une cinquantaine de vaisseaux.
Ce tycoon est plus qu'un simple transporteur de l'espace. C'est un jeu de stratégie, de management très pointu. Il m'a fallu de nombreuses parties pour en réussir une et atteindre le premier pallier des achèvements, à savoir atteindre les 1 million de dollars en liquide.
La gestion des flux se fait au jour le jour, car les prix des ressources demandées sur chaque planetoide varient régluièrement et c'est ce que personnellement je trouve géant. Il faut toujours rester à l'affut. On pense devoir envoyer des dizaines de fusée sur Titan, alors qu'il faut d'abord se focaliser sur la lune, puis mercure, les planètes et lunes les plus proches, avant de partir plus loin, car le coût en carburant des longs voyages englouti les profits, avant de pouvoir accéder à des vaisseaux consommant moins de carburant.
je recommande ce jeu si vous rechercher un challenge.
Oui le jeu n'est pas encore parfait, puisqu'il est toujours an accès anticipé, mais il est pas mal traduit en français, encore quelques mots non traduits, mais cela ne gène pas et personnellement j'y prend beaucoup de plaisirs. En plus de nouveaux vaisseaux, arbres technologiques vont arriver bientôt.
Son prix est très correct de mon point de vue, mais si vous n'aimez pas faire face à des petits bugs, problèmes, etc, attendez qu'il sorte en version finale :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197969096617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1559762753}
review:
The Short:

For a game that touts itself as having realistic business mechanics, the economics of this game are the farthest from reality I have seen in a business sim/space sim. Unbalanced AI and extremely poor optimization (and game visuals that further cripple it), make me wonder if this game will ever be worth it.

The Long:

Most of my initial 2 hours of playing was mostly frustrated restarting, not out of difficulty learning the game, but trying to find settings that actually worked without crippling stuttering. As someone who plays Stellaris and Civ games with the largest possible maps and max players with little to no lag, I was surprised that the only setting that wasnt annoying to play  on was the equivalent of setting everything to 30%. Anymore than 30 star systems and 4 players total, was just bad. This should have sent red flags to devs long ago, and I'm hoping they are fixing it.

My big grievance with this game, and the core reason I won't recommend it, is that currently the economic mechanics of this game are just idiotic. Here is the breakdown of why I think that:

1. I can pay a massive sum to colonize a planet, but I can't block my competitors from using that planet. I get absolutely no money from that colony in return.

2. I can subsidize and build factories, I get absolutely no income from those factories. My competitors can use the resources produced by those factories, and I can too, but I have to pay for them.

3. Distance does not seem to be calculated in the price of goods sold, which, if this is really aiming to just be a transport company game, is illogical. I know when I use Fedex, that shipping to Antarctica is the same price as shipping within my home state (sarcasm).

In simple, there is no reason to colonize or build infrasture. Wait for the AI to do it, then go for it. This is not how economies work. This saps all interest from the game for me. The current mechanics are like a communist tried to make a game focused on capitilism, with the main idea being "If you have money, you should spend it so everyone can use the fruits of your labor, including all your competitors for free of charge and 100% of the expense on you, you will not be compensated for you work comrade."

I'm a business owner in real life.. If someone came to me and asked me to build a factory, that my competitors would utilize, and I would get no direct income from, I would laugh in their face. Calling this game economic realism is flat, false advertising unless there is some major mechanic upgrades and changes on the way.

Pros & Cons

Pros -

Graphics - The games does a great job of various planets and vessels.
Procedural Generation - I never encountered a system that was the same as the last

Cons -

Extremely poor game optimization
Nonsensical and unrealistic economics
Unsustainable large amounts of micromanaging
developer_response:
Hi Ritsuka, thank you for your feedback and for your support!

Firstly, performance is something that is hit or miss for people, many can run 40 systems with no issue and have mediocre PCs, a few have issues with 20 systems on low settings.  I'm sorry you ran into this, we are working on locating the issue and correcting it.  The biggest factor on performance is the number of star systems.  We're thinking of limiting it to maybe 25 or 30 systems since any more really can cause headaches performance-wise and there's really no gameplay advantages to having more systems than that.  We're working on it.

Next I want to address your issues with subsidizing factories and colonies..  Colonizing a planet gives you a large reputation bonus which is important.  Also it opens up a market that wasn't available previously and if that is advantageous to you, that's great, if not colonizing is worthless.  You are not playing a government, you have no permission to block people from using resources on a planet etc...  You are a company focused on transportation which brings me to my second point.  Subsidizing a factory does not mean you have constructed it and are reaping benefits from it directly, you simply subsidized an industry.  Again if that's something that would benefit your transportation business, great, if not, don't do it.  All that being said, we are looking at maybe giving players ~25% of the goods produced by industries they subsidize since this is a serious issue and flaw in the system and can lead to frustration and confusion.  As you said, it's also not all that realistic.  From a gameplay standpoint we really want to make sure the player is focused on transportation though, not managing personal colonies and industries.  It's just too messy and exploitable otherwise.

Also you mentioned distance not directly influencing prices, this is true and definitely intentional.  If you've played TTD, it was easy to "exploit" that game's pricing systems, ignore the close markets and just focus on the longest distance transportation possible.  This definitely isn't how things work in reality.  If a market was ignored they would pay more for the goods to be transported to them and more for the goods.  While it's not 100% realistic to only use supply / demand on the price of transportation it is far more realistic than TTD's method and makes for much more "realistic" pressures on the player when deciding where to setup new routes etc...  EVERYTHING in ITC is based on supply / demands and it makes for a very interesting simulation IMO.

Finally you mentioned micromanaging, this is definitely true in mid and late game!  We will be adding in autonomous transportation options in the coming months.  There will be more info on it in November most likely.

I hope when we approach full launch I can get you to take another look at the game and hopefully turn this review around!  Keeping our players happy is very important to us.
