review:
This game has great potential. It’s an original idea and the mechanics work - the game is definitely in a playable state.

What the game needs is additional depth. Potential enhancements include:
1) Planets changing as you develop them. Do you look green eventually? Do you see cities? I’m not sure what ‘development’ could be, but something to see would be nice.
2) The ability to turn off the ship icons that sit over ships so you can see just the ship. This would improve realism. Potentially a cinematic view mode would be beneficial.
3) More trading options between new planets, not just from the main habitable planet to other planets.
4) Better ship management system to ‘bulk convert’ ship loadouts when a new planet doesn’t need certain resources anymore (eg machinery maxed out). A warning system here would also be useful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023722354', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1521950623}
review:
I really, really like the concept of this game. I'm a long fan of transport games since Transport Tycoon, and space transportation is one concept that I've never expected. Amazing approach.

However, at this moment, I would not recommend this game.

1) Poor user interface
Interface windows are too big, to they blocks main gameplay screen. If I open planet info, route list, and spaceship list, they fill up my screen so I can't see anything going on my transport network.
It would be much better if windows are resizable or font size can be adjusted.

2) Poor abstraction of cargo system
Let's think of the legendary Transport Tycoon. They have cities and industries. Industries will produce fixed goods at fixed rate. All the thing I should to do is to estimate cargo amount, to connect them, and to leave them doing well.
This game provide several types of cargo, which supply and demand is dynamically fluctuating over time. This means I must check the efficiency of previously made routes regularly. This is pain to me because it blocks me from making my new route to Titan. Because there is an AI competitor, I even can't take full control the supply condition.
That is why i said "poor abstraction". I can't control all the details simulated in a game. I need proper level of abstraction of reality, so I can play with it.
For me, transportation simulation game is to continuosly expanding my transport network while old routes are doing well as is. Old routes can be reivewed after 10 or 20 years when the vessels are aged and complete route redesign is required. This is because of good abstraction in game design about all the complicated details of the route management.
Some sort of automation of route control would be another solution to that.

3) Too many possible routes
Traditional 'terran' transport games have terrain factor, which limits route construction attempt between spots. This is obstacle for players, but also helps player to limit possibility of routes that could be constructed.
In this game, we came to space, so there is no obstacle. this yields too many possible routes to player.
Earth to Luna is OK. Earto to Mars? Fine. What about Mars to Luna? What about Calisto to Titan? This comes to N:N matching problem. I don't think human player can accurately decide what is the best route among those possible routes.
Some kind of mechanics should be there to limit route design. For example, hub-and-spoke design can be promoted by limiting interplanetary route in some ways.

In summary, this game is awesome, and well simulates real space transportation mechanics. However, it is too complicated to follow as a gameplay, and poor UI hinders it even more.
If there is a real space transportation company consists of several route managers and I'm just CEO, I can control it. In this game, I must do my role as CEO while doing regional route managers' task also. It's too hard for me, and it is beyond entertainment.

I really anticipate further improvements in this game. Ans thank developers for realizing this amazing game concept.

首先感谢SteamCN鉴赏家提供的游戏。Interstellar Transport Company，笔者译为“星际运输公司”，尚在EA阶段。

这是一款以太空为背景的模拟经营型策略游戏，玩家需要扮演一家星际运输公司的老板，规划线路，殖民和建设星球，并买船进行各种资源货物的运输工作，赚取利润并击败你的竞争对手。

笔者玩过的模拟经营类游戏不多，所了解的大都如开罗游戏，过山车大亨，天际线这种比较有名的。而这款游戏玩法着重于线路规划和资源调配，具体玩法和游戏性笔者将在下面一一进行分析。

画面与音乐：
游戏由Unity引擎开发，画面是简约风格的，模型较为简陋。当然这种模拟经营游戏的卖点并不在于画面，过于绚丽的效果反而会影响玩家的操作。游戏的界面设计比较简洁，玩家可以方便快捷的辨识和操作。音乐比较单调，但属于不易感到烦躁的那种，把原生BGM关了换网易云后台放自己喜欢的音乐完全可以，不会对游玩造成影响。总体上中规中矩吧。

性能与优化：
游戏程序支持64或32位系统，仅看最低配置对内存有一定要求。实际游戏过程中，CPU占用大概在10%-25%，属于低要求。而内存消耗前期不高，随着游戏进行，可以达到4G多，可见内存占用是比较厉害的。同时，优化也存在一定问题，前期很流畅，随着游戏进行，帧数会缓慢下降，游戏后期帧数不足30而且不稳定，甚至有时会跌到个位数。

玩法与游戏性：
大体玩法，规划路线-买船运输赚钱-建设已有星球，分配资源生产-殖民新星球，反复在这一过程中赚钱，需要统筹规划各个方面，同时与对手公司竞争。获胜条件，击垮竞争对手，使其亏损负债最终倒闭，胜利后仍然可以继续玩下去，无尽地赚钱。多人模式BUG很多，还不完善。所有目前主要是对抗AI，有快速竞赛和自定义游戏两种模式。教程很基础，经过几个引导关卡后就初步上手了。然后在正式的游戏中慢慢体会经营规划的精妙之处。单人游戏可以虽然暂停和调节时间流速，这也是经典的设定。亮点在于，不同游戏内资源、资金相关数值模型较为完善，成功而忙碌的管理需求和大量舰船飞行的繁忙场面将带给玩家满足和充实感。也许初期并不吸引人，但慢慢发展后会逐渐欲罢不能，和玩《文明》系列有类似的感觉。缺陷在于，内容还比较少，发展模式单一，让人在游玩时间达到一个阀值后缺乏重玩的动力。简单来说，就是前期上手一般，中期沉浸体验良好，后期缺乏重玩价值。

开发与本地化：
EA游戏往往会有两种结局，一个是受众慢慢增加，最终开发者至少能回本，另一个就是“鬼”，没人玩，开发者最后放弃。这款游戏目前处于充满潜力的阶段，开发者对游戏很上心，不断完善内容修复bug，乐于倾听玩家的反馈，更新较为频繁，这个势头是良好的。本地化方面游戏有官方中文，可惜汉化不全且机翻问题严重。笔者强烈建议英文进行游戏。考虑到团队规模，至少等正式版出来后才可能解决了。

总评
+玩法有趣，有挑战性
+模型和数值系统严谨
+世界宏大
-测试阶段存在BUG、优化、汉化等等不完善的方面
-过程缺乏多样性

review:
Good game and good concept but it's almost unplayable late game. I wrote a previous review which I removed when the dev told me about some recent updates which would fix many of the issues, and planned to write a new one once I'd played the game with the updates. I can see the user interface has been changed since I last played and now allows you to resize windows which is useful, but there are still improvements I think it needs, such as the ability to copy settings from routes to allow you to set up new ones a bit quicker.

The main issue right now though is how badly optimised the game is. Once you get to the late game, its unplayable. I had to sit in an empty solar system with no GUI windows open to minimise the lag. If I tried sit in the main system, it just constantly stutters. Maybe if there was a way to disable the ship icons it'd reduce the lag a bit. The GUI also becomes very laggy too in the late game. When I'd try set up a new route, I'd click to the planet on the list and it'd take a good 5 or 6 seconds before it'd bring it up. I have a fairly good pc too. I7-7700 with 16GB RAM and a GTX 1060 and a 500 GB SSD. For a game with such basic graphics it shouldn't lag this much. If the only thing they improved was the optimisation to prevent all the lag then I'd be able to recommend the game, despite the not so great UI, but right now once you're sending ships to more than 3 or 4 planets it becomes unplayable.

I really hope the game will be improved because I really like the concept and I did enjoy playing the game during the early game when there wasn't so much lag, but right now I can't recommend it.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

>>>>Edit<<<< 18/05/2019 

I've taken another look at the game since the developer responded telling me of optimisations and improvements to the game. I've spent another 10 hours on the game now looking at the changes but still can't recommend anyone buys this game.

One of the biggest problems is still the lag. For a game with quite simple graphics, it doesn't run very smoothly at all. I notice there is now a way to turn off competitor ship icons and routes, but cant find any option to turn off my own to try reduce the lag.

Drones are game breaking. Once you get some drone hubs and the tech to allow them to land on any planet without a landing spot then there's not much else left to do.

Luxury resources dont seem well balanced. Earth wasn't even producing enough for itself and I could find no way to improve it. Once you get below the threshhold for transporting them, then you can no longer build weapons (Are they made of solid gold or something?)

Interstellar colonisation also takes way too long. It took hours just to get a planet to 100% development, and even then it would take hours longer to get enough resources to that planet to be able to colonise other planets in the system.

Another huge issue is the auto save feature. They list alphabetically rather than based on the last save that happened, so if you've played multiple games you have to scroll through them. You also cant middle mouse wheel or click a button to move up and down, you have to just grab the bar and move it. It can get very difficult to get to the right save if you have a lot of files there. There were many autosaves (They don't seem to remove older ones) so I decided to delete my save files to clear it up. After finding the location of them, I found almost 3,000 files which totalled to 10gb of space being used up on my hard drive. 

I'd recommend this game if it was £5 or less but for the £19.99 price tag there's far better games you could spend your money on.

Let me be clear. It's janky. It's quite janky, especially in multiplayer.

Even for this game with a very small playerbase, updates still come frequently and regularly. If you get this game at this point, you can be a very active part of the development. Suggestions and bug reports get responded to within the day, generally, and patch notes frequently include features that were suggested the day before.

If you can stomach a buggy, but fundamentally solid game, if you can deal with savegames corrupting in weird ways, if you can submit bug supports and suggestions, if you like logistics and/or space, I'd recommend it.

I can 100% say that I've fully gotten my money's worth already and the game just might have a bright future.

10/10, would sell machinery to a dead colony again.

review:
Interstellar Transport Company is a great simulation game for those who like depth and choice. The game definitely still has rough edges (it's in early access after all) but the core mechanics are quite solid.

Pros:
* Many ships & cargo types to choose from mean you can try a lot of different ways to make money
* Having a lot of different routes and types of cargo moving around feels really rewarding after scrimping and saving to maximize profits
* I've already lost hours to this game by getting sucked into the fun of min/maxing profits on each of my routes and checking out new ship types. Getting into the flow of the game is very enjoyable, especially once you start seeing profits roll in!

Cons:
* Some of the UI elements aren't very clear, e.g., what does cargo maintenance 90% mean exactly?
* Ships don't haul specific amounts of cargo, e.g., 10 units of food, they just have bulk storage that could be food, consumer goods, rare resources &c. This can make it difficult to know if you're properly meeting demand for a colony or just bringing more resources they're already swimming in.
* Game isn't totally finished, so don't expect a ton of content & new ships after 25 years of in-game time

review:
This game is in Early Access. So I am writing a review to reflect that i expect bugs/ issues in this game and do not class them as a negative feature. So mentions of bugs will not be included in this review, as an Early Access game is not a finished project. 

This game has takes some planning and you really have to follow the market carefully. There are some good guides on You Tube to help new players get started and there is a discord chat where you can report bugs/fixes and ask for advice about the game from the devs or more experienced players. The game community is very friendly and helpful. Someone will always help you out when needed. 

The Devs really care about this game they are making. There are frequent patches to perform bug fixes and improve the game and the devs are available to talk to on the game discord server. They appreciate their players and are listening to us to help improve this game with every patch. 

You supply earth and colonies on planet with colonists, and resources. You compete with Ai companies to supply these items and to start new colonies in our solar system. There is  a choice of rockets and ships and all have stats on fuel efficiency. On new planets you can build a spaceport and then lease space gates for your ships and rockets. There is also multiplayer available in this game, but I have yet to use this feature. On the discord server you will find plenty of people who play multiplayer that you can join. We start in our solar system and there is the capacity for expansion into other solar systems. I can get lost in this game for hours, there are so many possibilities and scenarios that no 2 simulations are the same. 
 All in all I would recommend this game to fans of economy driven games. Give it a try, and you will see how much fun this can be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993451081', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1511444191}
review:
If you're a fan of tycoon games, this one is probably for you.  This title offers you the opportunity to start out with a small fleet of ships schlepping food and water to the Moon and transform it into a titan of interstellar commerce.  Will you assist humanity in spreading out to colonize the solar system and beyond?  Or will you operate solely to satisfy your own avaricious desire for cash?  Will you pay to found a colony on Titan that can produce fuel to aid the conquest of the stars?  Or will you ship thousands of forlorn colonists out to the barren moons of Neptune empty-handed, then make a mint selling them the food and water they need to survive but are incapable of producing themselves?

The choice is yours, and Interstellar Transport Company leaves the player free to operate in whatever fashion they desire while the AI opponents engage in similar schemes in an effort to undercut, outpace, or overwhelm you.  The overall mechanics of the game are relatively simple, and yet still manage to produce a surprising variety of emergent game play.  No two runs of Interstellar Transport Company feel the same, and yet are similar enough that the basic skills you learn in your first few runs will soon have you wheeling and dealing like Warren Buffet crashing his Ferrari through the main doors of the Bellagio in Vegas.

It is worthwhile to note, however, that the game is still in Early Access.  There are a few bugs that occasionally crop up with some AI behaviors (like not building maintenance sheds to fix damaged ships) and the user interface is a bit counter-intuitive and difficult to use.  But despite those flaws, there's still certainly enough going on in Interstellar Transport Company to provide you with a sizable amount of entertainment for the price.

We are forced to do this part-time during our free time due to limited sales and resources.  I'm glad that you got 100 hours of play (hopefully most enjoyable) from the game in it's early state and am surprised you decided to harm our efforts even further with a negative review.

Also, keep in mind that multiplayer tests and gameplay often highlight imbalances and issues that would never be visible just playing against AI or alone.

We are doing the best we can, and are very proud of how far we've come so far.  However, the game is in early access, we have stated many times that there will be bugs and that the game is incomplete.  If anyone looking at this game wants a complete, polished and bug free game, please wait for full launch, this game is very much in development.

A well worth game keep up the great work to the devs

author: {'steamid': '76561198030752471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 19458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6702, 'last_played': 1593868383}
review:
Excellent:
Theme. The game brings this out very well. It really feels like you are running the company that is responsible for the interstellar expansion of humanity. The visuals work well. The planets look cool. The ships have fun names. The line of ships you get going from home, out a colony, and back looks good. It is satisfying to see the progress as a colony develops. It feels like you are working to established permanent homes other worlds. 

Strategy. You have a lot of choices. You are always deciding what ships to buy, what they should carry, and what route they should take. You usually have options that are either "cheaper and better now" or "more expensive and better later." You always have "things to work on." You can choose where new colonies will go. You can tinker with current trade routes to make them more profitable.


Good to Mixed:
Balance. The overall balance seems good for what has been released. There are subtle changes that could improve things, and I think the devs have their eye on that. (They have made a few balance changes since the game was released and all the changes were steps in the right direction.) Later game stuff does need more work, and this is on the dev roadmap forward.

Replayablilty: Generally one game versus another does progress in a similar way. You have information about what is needed and you take care of that. If Mars needs more water you buy a new water ship and send it to Mars. You can get a long way just by playing this way. That said, after a few games you understand more of the subtlties and can min/max your trade routes. I find that I enjoy trying to minimize extra costs and squeeze out maximum profit.

The UI. The UI has improved greatly with the latest patch. It seems that this is where the devs are currently focusing. It does take some getting used to, but with the new changes I feel like I have the tools I need.

The AI. I have played a number of games both with AI opponents and as the only company. Honestly, I've never felt like the AI opponents add much to the game. In games with AI opponents, they sometimes help get colonies going a bit faster, but usually I just notice them doing thing that I wouldn't do because it's inefficient. Generally they serve as a minor hinderance. By late game the AI doesn't have much of a presence. For me, the game is less about beating my opponents, and more about establishing a huge interstellar trade network. Whether the AI is present or not only affects that a little. Also, I have found games without AI opponents to be more fun. Without the AI you have more control in things like in fine-tuning demand without causing famine and deciding what colonies should get limited resourses. If playing against a competitive AI is important to you, this game might not be the right choice. If you aren't worried about the AI and your priority it to build up your trade empire, the weak AI won't hinder that. Also try playing without any AI opponents.


Reasons to wait a bit:
Lack of detailed information. Much of the financial numbers are "under the hood" at this point. There are ways to estimate the cost of a given trade route if you work it out. The calulations that go into how much a route earns is a mystery. The Devs have said that this is on their radar. 

There are a few bugs (It's still in alpha). The devs have been doing a good job of dealing with these, but some can be annoying. That said, in my last game, there weren't any bugs that prevented me from making progress. 


Overall:
I'm having a lot of fun. The theme is great. Bringing 500 million people to an interstellar Earth-like planet is satisfying. I find that I want to try out new strategies and maximize my income. The devs are working to make the game better, and it is improving. I certainly think it is worth the price in its current state.

review:
Jeu en alpha. J'hésitais beaucoup à l'acheter étant donné son prix. Je ne le regrette pas. 
Certaines fenêtres nous oblige souvent à tourner la tête dans tout les sens pour pouvoir lire correctement un texte beaucoup trop petit et parfois clairement illisible, mais au bout d'un peu moins de deux heures de jeu, je ne peux que recommander Interstellar Transport Company qui tourne très bien sur un peu n'importe quoi.

Les graphismes sont pas excellents, dans le sens où ils pourraient être meilleurs. Je suis facilement dérangé par ce côté-ci d'un jeu, mais ici, ça ne m'a pas rebuté. En lui même ITC n'est pas très compliqué à prendre en main, même si certain chose ne sont pas TOTALEMENT logique (baisse de la popularité de la Companie sur X planète lorsqu'on finance un centre policier pour maintenir les pirates à l'écart ?).

Les petits évents sont sympathiques. Comme par exemple les prix en hausse de la nourriture sur tel astre, où les réfugiés d'une famine grondante sur un autre. 

Malgré tout, le système d'accroissement de population reste arbitraire. Il suffit bêtement de faire des routes de transport pour mener million par million, des hommes d'affaires ou des colons sur Venus, par exemple.

Achetez ce jeu en promos seulement. Je recommande !

review: I've given this game a thumbs up, but thats only if the game gets plenty of extra work in it. as it is, its an enjoyable game for a few hours but once you get past the new game experience, its lack of depth and flaws become apparent. I really hope the devs keep adding to the game and make a load of much needed changes and additions the game sorely needs as, as it is right now, although playable it needs a lot of love. For a economic trading game it doesnt give you enough information, it tells you supply and demand but doesnt go anyt further than saying it wants "this" and supplies "this" and although a lot of other games have done similar in the past to good effect, this game leaves you feeling unconnected and detached and not really involved in the planets success or failure. Also there doesnt seem to be any real reason to spend your own companies money on buildings on a planet as there doesnt seem to be any real positive from doing it besides from being able to sell more of that resource as the planet takes ownership of the building. To me that seems pretty stupid, I spend 290,000 of my own money to find that all ive done is made it that theres more resources on the planet that anyone can buy and I make nothing from it except what I ship myself. would rather spend my money on a ship and buy the resource elsewhere. also I thought you would be able too corner markets or even whole planets but atm it doesnt seem like you can at all, all your doing is buying a ship setting up a route and sending it off to make money to buy another ship and carry on the process without feeling like your accomplishing anything, or getting anything out of it on the whole. also atm your reputation on planets doesnt seem to have any real effect to yourself or the game at first i was buying a  headquarters on a planet thinking it would benefit me but then noticed my reputation was pretty much the same as i was delivering too on planets without a headquarters. But its not all bad even though im making it sound like it is. Its only in alpha, and the core of the game is there and it has the possibilty in becomming a great game but it needs a lot of work and attention.i doubt il play the game over the next few months, but I will come back and I am hoping the devs will of put atleast some of the things it needs into the game to make it feel immersive and like your actually doing something worthwhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053788131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1504522341}
review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
Interstellar Transport Company (ITC) is the second Steam title from indie developers, MT Worlds.

Departing from the developers' previous VR Sports title, ITC is a tycoon-style simulation game set in the near future. Set in 2050, with mankind beginning to colonise the other bodies in our solar system, ITC places you in charge of a fledgling space transport company supporting Earth's expansion.

The game begins with the moon (Luna) and Mars already colonised and with spaceports of varying sizes present on Earth, Luna, and Mars. You choose your company name and colour and then the galaxy is your oyster; purchase docking bays, set up trade routes, and make as much profit as you can while supplying the intrepid colonists with everything they need to survive and prosper on the planets and moons of Sol.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
ITC's graphics are a mixed bag. The planet and ship graphics are pretty, and the seemingly chaotic mess of satellites about heavily inhabited planets is excellent. But the little details, like the security ships with red/blue flashing lights that aren't lights and instead seem to just colour the whole surface of the ship in alternating red and blue, or the weird scale of the ships and space port compared to the planets themselves, detracts. I mean, is the spaceport above Earth REALLY supposed to be as big as Africa!?

The interface is what you'll be looking at most of the time and it's quite large and ugly, with some icons that don't really resemble much (I really hope they're just placeholders!). It's unfortunate that it's confusing, too. Does a button labelled "disable tooltips" mean tooltips are currently enabled and clicking on it will disable them? I'm not sure. And why can you zoom out from a planet to reach system level, but zooming back in does NOT take you back to the planet? And you can't zoom out from system level to galaxy level either. ESCAPE takes you from planet to system, too, but not system to galaxy; for that you can only right-click. They're just a few examples. It's inconsistent and rather poor HCI design.

I also noticed a weird anomaly popping up on occasion: a faded red icon floating in space near Earth. I couldn't work out what caused it, but it happened a few times.

There are a few graphics options to play around with. I set everything to maximum and the game moved along smoothly.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The sound in ITC is pretty lacking, but at the same time I think it's probably sufficient for this type of game. I think there's only one music track: a relatively slow sort of ambient electronic track with assorted electronic sounds and various riffs. I'm thinking "sci-fi industrial ambient" might be a new sub-genre to categorise it.

Sound effects are minimal. Interface response bleeps are a bit loud and the bottle-breaking (?) sound when a new ship is built is terrible.

There are no voices.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
I have to confess that after my first hour with ITC I was ready to give it a miss. If I'd bought it and been wondering whether to refund it I would have been on the fence. Then I started reading some more of the tooltips and realised there's a lot more depth than first impressions suggest, and the very limited tutorial really doesn't do it justice. The tutorial explains how some of the more common parts of the interface work, but that's it. It's more like guided technical documentation on a small part of the UI than a proper tutorial.

The game proper begins when you start a new pre-defined or custom game. Though the tutorial recommends the former, I'd suggest the latter might be more fun for beginning players, as it lets you customise the number of AI companies as well as the galaxy size and, importantly, your starting cash. Regardless of which you choose there's an inevitable "Now what!?" moment when you begin.

The basic gameplay is very limited. You set up trade routes among the planets and moons that have been colonised and you buy and fit out space ships to ply those routes. And that's it. There are single-use rockets that are cheap and fast to build, and let you deliver resources even if you don't have a space port lease at the other end, and larger multiple-use ships that require a certain level of space port to build, and a lease at a certain level at the other end in order to land. You choose the types of cargo bays fitted when you create a ship and there's no way to change it later.

It was only after I'd been playing for a couple of hours, making tons of money, but becoming rather bored, that I started to wonder what the rather abstract resources I'd been transporting actually represented, and then I discovered the game's hidden depths. Each colony requires people, obviously, but also machinery in order to efficiently produce other goods. Dilithium crystals -- a rather rare mineral, I discovered -- are required for interstellar travel, but you need to find them first.

After I discovered these hidden depths I became far more interested in the game. The early stages are all about positioning your company for further expansion, but with very limited tutorials it was only through distracted fiddling that I found out anything about this. In Sol, everything hinges on Titan. 

Even after this discovery I still felt a bit overwhelmed by the game's deficiencies. I'm sure the developers will make progress -- after all, that's what Early Access is all about. Here's a short list of some of my current complaints, anyway:

- No automatic pause in management or system menus.
- It's easy for your ships to sit there doing nothing. It needs alerts for idle resources.
- It's hard to see a ship's current location.
- Fuel usage isn't explained. How does this work? Does it matter for interplanetary (not interstellar) runs?
- Finding buildings on a planet is more difficult than it should be.
- Orbits always seem to be circular!?
- How does speed affect efficiency. Each ship should have a tonnage/speed efficiency rating.
- What does "Player Difficulty" setting mean in a custom game? Surely that depends on the player!? 
- No way to edit cargo bays on an existing ship. Why not?
- No way to ensure a ship is completely full before it leaves; passenger compartments almost always leave empty.
- Can't tell at a glance which resources are going to be picked up and which ones aren't; it's annoying clicking on each resource to check its current settings.
- Ships will launch with some bays empty on their first flight. MAJOR issue.
- No way to specify a save name -- it looks like there should be, but it ignored me and used an autosave slot.
- Everything moves slightly to the left when decreasing time speed or to the right when increasing it.
- Duplicate ship button doesn't work well. Starting point and auto-launch aren't duplicated properly.
- Order ship button sometimes stops working entirely, requiring a restart.

In spite of the frustrations above, and my first impressions -- no research, no ship upgrades, and limited buildings available -- the core mechanics are sound and there's a lot of potential. The balance between transport and production is a good one. If the interface can be fixed and the bugs ironed out, ITC could be a rather impressive game.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]
Pros:
+ Hidden depths
+ Some lovely graphics
+ Achievements

Cons:
- Fiddly, ugly, inconsistent interface
- Some depths are too well hidden
- Buggy

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Interstellar Transport Company has potential, but it definitely needs work. The tutorial is basic and much of the game's more interesting detail is hidden in tooltips. The core gameplay is interesting, but can be slow to start and currently requires too much micromanagement to work around bugs. The UI needs a major overhaul; at the moment basic tasks require too much effort. It's also rather buggy, but in Early Access one has to expect that.

review:
Let's get this out first: this is a game with a huge amount of potential and I truly enjoy the core concepts, but it falls apart quickly due to a combination of poor AI, data transparency and UI design. Have put 10 hours into the game across three play-throughs, two of which went past 20 years, both of those having kicked off interstellar colonization.

At this point I'm putting the game down and won't be coming back until some key items are addressed. I'm taking the time to put this together because I enjoy what the game could be and can easily see myself putting another 50+ hours into the game with some minor adjustments. Please take the feedback below in that lens.

The Good:

-Core delivery model - It's Space Truck Simulator 2017, plain and simple. All the right bones are there and when it clicks, it feels very good.
-Theme comes through - I feel like I'm running a logistics company, spread across a harried amount of demands.
-Runs well on my crap laptop - It's a really crap laptop and the game still loads super fast and handles quite well. Exceptions to this are when I'm spamming rockets with the ships and colony screen open, then it goes to crap.
-Not fair - I'm a big fan of hard games that point you to a big wall and let you fall flat on your face. This certainly fits the bill, although there are issues here I'll address below.

The Bad:

-Very limited data transparency - I'll be honest, this is a huge one for me. This is at it's core a market game and we have no view of market prices. Big miss. Going beyond that, there's no view into the variables that impact things. Event (famine, etc.) modifiers, population supply/demand drivers, basic colony supply/demand view, potential growth view, fuel costs, maintenance costs, in transit goods view, company reputation impact, etc. None of this is icing on the cake stuff, it's all core requirements to having a market based game. Look to Paradox games for suggestions on top notch tool tip views.
-Shoddy menu UI - I'm at the stage where I want to murder something every damn time I need to buy a new ship, especially once I'm in the mid-game 100+ ships deep. Let's order three ship copies for an existing delivery line... pause the game so the ship menu doesn't glitch out, find the ship in an unsortable list, duplicate the ship, edit and copy the ship name for consistency, oh it jumped back up to the top now scroll back down, rename the ship and save, oh it jumped back up to the top, let me scroll back down... sigh.
-Terrible AI companies - There's not much to explain here, the AI companies will hold strong on unfair difficulty for the first 5 years or so and then start falling apart. Plenty of demand and money to be made, but they can't seem to make a steady profit beyond that point and collapse like a poorly made flan. This compounds the issue of growing colony needs, as the AI companies won't fill the gaps like they should, leaving it all up to the player.
-No AI replacement or generation - The game doesn't seem to close out failing AI companies and refresh them, nor will it generate new companies on the fly for specific needs. Both of my 20+ year games have ended with only my company ships in the skies.
-Unclear expectations - The game doesn't give you a feel for what's expected by colony. Part of this goes into the above, as the game doesn't outright tell you "hey man, this planet really can't grow crap, you should really pay attention here," it'll just hit you with famines. Not to say it's not an indicator of failure, but it's not readily obvious out of the gate and certainly doesn't give you a feel for what to focus on until you have a game or two of failure under your belt. 
-No menu filtering - What I would give to be able to sort ships by route, or tag ships as certain types (food, passenger, etc.). Finding specific ships to view, copy, replace, etc. is really painful right now.

What's Making Me Walk Away:

-Crap AI companies
-Poor menu UI
-Extremely limited data view

Looking forward to what the game can become, especially after these key issues are addressed, but will be putting it down entirely until then. Completely understand that this is in an early alpha state, and that combined with how much I enjoy the core gameplay is why I'm taking the time to provide this feedback. Hope this helps, for what it's worth.

review:
this is a very EA game.. there is really no substance to it atm, so writing a review this early is somewhat of a difficult proposition because you dont want to say the game is bad as its so early... 

The game is basic... whilst it is an economics simulator built in space in reality right now there is no real economics to work on other than supply and demand, you dont know the cost of anything until you build a route.  

simplistically, find surplus, find demand, buy ship, deliver until demand is fullfilled .. create demand on new planets... repeat...

in single player there is no 'winning' of the game developed.. atm you cant  buy or sell stock in other companies ..you basically just get compared to other companies to know if you are better at managing your cash flow, have more routes, ships etc... 

it only launched EA this month so a lot and I mean a lot still to do to make this anywhere near a satisfying space tycoon game.. lots of feedback from users which is good although you would hope that the devs have a road map that they are building towards other than integrating user feedback....

can I recommend?  its no where near a complete game so as a game right now no, if you want a tycoon sim in space and want to get involved early then yes.. but as usual I really disagree with Steam allowing dev companies to use it as a means of early funding and getting bug/feedback for free with the possibility that it will never be completed.

review:
개인적으로 매우 마음에 드는 게임이다. 개인적인 취향에도 맞기도 하다.
우주 경영으로 행성간 운송이 주요 내용이다. 행성의 발전에도 개입하지만, 직접적인 영향은 거의 없다.
과거 리뷰에서 언급했던 우주선의 관리가 어렵다는 점은 해결되었다.
그러나 단점들은 여전히 많다.
우선 한번 하는데 걸리는 시간이 매우 길다. 
현재 최종컨텐츠는 항성간 수송이라고 할수있는다.

다른 문제는 그래픽및 게임 디자인에 비해 게임이 너무 무겁다는 것이다. 
후반에 들어서면 아무리 좋은 컴퓨터도 10~12fps로 나오며, 새로운 우주선을 만들기위해 생산버튼을 누르면 몇초씩 멈춘다. 엔진의 한계인것인지 게임 자체의 문제인 것인지는 모르겠다. 또한 메모리를 너무 많이 필요로 한다. 나같은경우는 8GB의 메모리를 혼자서 점유하고 있을 정도다.
sf장르를 좋아하는 사람들이 이 게임을 좋아할수 있을지는 모르겠지만, 경영물을 좋아한다면 이 게임을 좋아할것이다.
하지만 2017년 10월 7일 기준으로는 구매를 추천하지 않는다. 좀더 업데이트를 기다리는것이 좋을것이다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977555389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1610, 'last_played': 1563689311}
review:
This game is a logistics simulator with a space theme. 

You play as a space trucking company competing against up to 7 others (up to 7 AI in single player games; haven't tried multiplayer yet). Supply and demand drives prices for resources that you need to transport between planets and moons as humanity colonizes the solar system and beyond. Choose different types of ships for your transport fleet based on your needs. Some ships are faster than others, carry more cargo, are more reliable, etc. 

I started off binging on this game as it was alot of fun to get into (and i really like logistics for some reason). I slowed down a bit later, since the game can get a bit repetitive and overwhelming with the amount of ships you have. However, I find myself thinking about new strategies and wanting to test them out, an so I do. There is not a ton of depth, but the game's core seems to be built in such a way that would allow for alot of extra features and such from the devs.

Pros:
-Gameplay is pretty fun with a decent amount of strategy involved.
-Runs well on low-end systems (so I've heard)
-The game's foundation and core lends itself to being expanded upon alot
-Dev team seems extremely active (especially for only 4 people total on the project?) and has released like 4-5 patches in less-than-two week period since the game has been in EA.
-$20 price point seems spot-on.

Cons:
-Can be a bit boring if you're not that into logistics simulation.
-Has some bugs that can be fairly impactful to gameplay (what EA game doesn't?)
-Some UI elements and data transparency needs to have added elements (transaction history, price, etc), but basic UI so far is pretty decent. 

With any early access game, you need to be wary about the product your are buying. However, with the current game state (I still have fun playing it) and the dev activity (extremely active), I have no regrets buying this game and anticipate a lot of cool new features to be added to this game to really flesh out this gaming experience. At $20, this game has already given me more gameplay time than many other $20+ games.

As of now I would probably give this game a 7/10 in its current EA state. I'm looking forward to see how this game progresses and have high hopes for the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117391036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1503624008}
review:
The name says pretty much what this game is about, supply and demand.... 

The game has a really good platform, its interesting, it's fun to expand through your universe and the big leap to the next universe. 

I can say, as of right now, its good, you'll get your money's worth for sure (recommend playing by yourself first go around before throwing in AI)

The intial start is good, it feels immersive enough, you need to watch supply and demand (Earth being your hub for most of the resources you need) then start supplying the other planets as they develop... This will be fun for the first 4-6 hrs but things start to get a bit "overwhelming" in a manner. You also need to balance yourself against the AI that is also supplying, affecting demand... it felt like spamming one shot rockets in the beginning was the only way to give yourself a necessary boost of cash to compete easily with the AI, this still seems to to be ongoing throughout the game... spamming rockets to make some extra cash while managing an entire fleet feels like a click fest, speeding up and slowing the game down. 

6hrs or so in, here's the issues you run into...

The game starts to get less personal, you are dealing with bubbles (planets) and floating icons (ships) no detail anymore... this takes away any visual detail the game has to offer. 

You are manually going to each planet (or supply route) ensuring your ships are meeting the correct demand and they are turning a profit, this starts to get slightly exhausting because the UI isn't built efficiently for this. 

The scale of this game is huge and tapping into 1/10 of this game makes you wonder how they will keep the player engaged... you get to a point where you are cycling through planets and maximizing routes and thats it... and that's only 1/10 of the possible management... too much with little reward if at any... unless you just like dots and seeing money rise...

It would be interesting to see where this game goes in 6-12 months... if you want something more finished, I'd definitely wait, they are still tweaking major aspects of the base game while breaking a few things along the way at times.

review:
I've put about 20 hours into this game. And while there's still stuff I haven't done which I may do just to see if it changes my impression, I think, for the most part, I'm largely done.
It's a nice looking game, and there's much I like about it. But it has two gaping problems.
The first is depth - you can set up routes and ships to run on them, and fiddle them to make a profit. But once you've done that, it's just an exercise in doing it a bit more, and making a bit more money. There doesn't seem to be a goal. Even the inclusion of AI competitors is a bit shallow - because the AI never stops you from doing anything you might otherwise do. They're just there as decoration.
The second problem the game has is clutter. Most games like this, there are two ways of playing - conservatively where you gradually build up your organisation; or spamming. And whatever mode you play, the AI spams. As a result, very quickly, the shipping lanes are full of ships. Hundreds of them. And caring about the fate of your handful of ships in a universe where they awash with hundreds of other ships is difficult. They just become blocks to build your bottom line, and they essentially disappear.
This is a game in progress, and added depth and reduced clutter may happen down the track. But for now, it's a cute game with a limited lifespan.

Right now it's a ton of fun.  The roadmap of features to come look like they will make the game much better.  At the same time it's not overly ambitous.   So hopefully it will be done before too long.  The fact that so much of the game is already there inspires confidence in what the eventual final product will be.

I recommend you buy it.   But if you decide not to, keep an eye on the store page for sales and the eventual full release.  It can only get better.

review:
This game is Capitalism 2/Capitalism Lab in space. It's amazing. It's the most fun I've had in a tycoon-type game since RCT3.

The easy way to make money at the beginning of the game is to bring water, food and colonists to the Moon which kinda becomes your mining place, then choose between sending your raw materials to either Earth or developing a base on Mercury.


Eventually you'll have to colonize Titan for the crystals that are used to get to the rest of the solar system, but that's a bit of a dumpster fire right now in my game because I heavily favor high-capacity ships over fast ships and it's causing famine and drought on Titan and I now have an influx of refugees to Earth. It's fine. I'm a survivor, not a victim.

Two weaknesses:

1) It's early access which means it's got a bug or two. Nothing that caused a crash to desktop, but I did have to restart my game once. 

2. It's not optimized. After 5+ hours of a single play session on a single save (yes, it's THAT fun) my 6700K was brought to its knees any time I opened the "ships" window. It was fine when I closed that window even with tons of other stuff happening on screen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019994180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1588593139}
review:
Lots of potential for this game, and only really held back by the need for optimization. There's a sense of expansion at every step, and there's a sense of grandeur as you build your trading empire. However, if you haven't already figured out, there's really only one path currently to succeed at the game.

Hints if you are struggling to keep away from bankruptcy:

Machine and rare material production simply does not ramp up quickly enough, so it's pointless building machinery cargo on your ships. Right now, machinery is a newbie trap. Let the bots transport machinery, since it will quickly run out on Earth. You can get away with transporting only a small amount to make a little bit at the beginning of the game. Otherwise you will be wasting a lot of cargo room.

Once you unlock Jupiter's moons and the Gorman Dart, you can just transport 30-40% passengers and the rest water/food, and demand for food and water will quickly rise on that moon, activating a subsidy. You can easily just make millions off of it. I found this to be a very reliable way of racking up a large sum of money quickly.

Another tip is simply to cash in on Luna, then get to transporting food/water/passengers to Mars quickly. Luna makes a lot of money early, but it becomes pretty competitive once the AI starts transporting stuff. You will usually find yourself losing money after the development reaches 100%. 

Currently, development and population doesn't seem to have a large effect on resource production and resource profile. I hope that the devs will update this, so then planets can begin to produce more rare minerals and detritium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134637015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1504539124}
review:
I have played this game for just over 2 hours at the time of writing this,
bearing in mind that this game was release to early access just 2 days ago I think I have stumbled onto a gem.

Pros:
1.) Very complicated game, this means there is so much to learn about playing that you end up spending hours perfecting strategies, and given this is very early access, it will only get more complicated from here

2.) Huge amounts of gameplay, Earth and the Moon is only the first step, gradually the game expands onto a much larger scope, with each knew planet and star system being new yet helpfully similar, meaning there is potentially hours of enjoyable, non repetitive gameplay in each game.

3.) Competitive multiplayer gameplay (This feature is currently bugged, but is planned for future release) judging from how the game plays with one Human and multiple AI, there is the potential for incredibly competitive multiplayer games, as the basis of the game is to out compete your fellow space transport companies.

Things I am not sure about being a pro or a con:
1.) a simple tutorial system: the current tutorial (It will change as new features are implemented) is very simple, telling the player what each game system does, but not telling the player the best ways of effectively using each system to its advantage. I like this because it leaves the strategies to be figured out by the player, making the player spend hours figuring out what and when to do things.

unfortunately this also may lead players to think the game is impossibly hard and cause them to quit. 
2.) the game is Very hard, at least in my opinion.
this makes the game fun as it is a challenge to overcome but also can lead to boredom at failing every time you try to expand your buisness to mars instead of just the moon. (maybe I am just doing it so horrendously wrong that this isn't an issue?)

cons:
1.) a bit buggy in its current state, but no more than is to be expected of an early alpha
2.) Multiplayer is bugged, and custom matches bugged the last few times I tried them, nothing majour though, they will likely get patched/ implemented quite soon.

Summary:
A fun game with nice visuals and huge potential in the future. This is the type of game I, and likely many other players have been searching for.

review:
Я несколько раз садился за игру, играл пару часов и уходил, думая, что уже всё, надоело. Но нет, куда там! Думаешь, куда надо ещё послать корабли, как дальше будешь колонизировать галактику, как не допустить голода на Европе, получится ли развить колонию на землеподобной планете у соседней звезды и использовать её как плацдарм для дальнейшего освоения космоса и так до бесконечности, пока снова не сядешь за игру и не начнёшь придумывать новые маршруты, покупать новые корабли, развивать космопорты и рудниками на планетах.
Космос здесь в меру красивый для симулятора, но, главное, ощущается очень реалистичным, да, иногда твои корабли пролетают прямо сквозь Солнце как ни в чём не бывало, но это только потому, что они летят самым оптимальным маршрутом от Земли, которая совершает свой годовой оборот вокруг Солнца, к Титану, который обращается вокруг Юпитера, который в свою очередь, кружит вокруг Солнца. Да, это не так просто и это завораживает. Здесь реально понимаешь почему иногда до Марса от Земли лететь всего ничего, а иногда несколько астрономических едениц и почему это большая проблема космонавтики (да, у меня марсиане обходились несколько месяцев без воды и еды, чуть не пришлось их на Землю возвращать:). Здесь ты можешь спасти голодных беженцев с Альфы-Центавры, поселив их на Меркурии.
Это вот всё, эта власть над космосом, над развитием человеческой космической цивилизации очень захватывает. Сомневаюсь, что получится бросить играть до заселения всех ближайших звёзд в Галактике.

Interstellar Transport Company ist ein vielversprechender Early Access Titel für alle, die Freude an den Genres Management, Tycoon und Strategie haben. Fans von Spielen wie Transport Tycoon, Railroad Tycoon, Simutrans, Trainfever oder Transportfever, sollten die weitere Entwicklung verfolgen.

Das Spiel ist jetzt schon gut spielbar. Der Entwickler zeigt sich sehr aktiv. Besonders positiv fällt auf, dass der Entwickler persönlich auf Kommentare und Vorschläge der (noch) kleinen Community antwortet und eingeht. Über Twitter ist nachvollziehbar, dass einige Vorschläge direkt umgesetzt werden.

Das Spiel ist auf den ersten Blick nicht sehr komplex. Es gibt eine überschaubare Zahl an Ressourcen und anfangs noch nicht allzu viele Schiffstypen. Recht schnell zeigt sich aber die Komplexität, die sich schnell ergibt, wenn man über den ersten Planet hinaus Handel betreibt. Man beginnt in den Standarteinstelungen in unserem Sonnensystem und handelt zwischen Erde und Mond (Luna). Die ersten profitablen Routen sind schnell eingerichtet. Jetzt sollte man allerdings nicht denken, dass es das schon gewesen wäre. Will man weitere Planeten besiedeln, wird es zunehmend schwer, die richtige Balance zwischen den Ressourcen zu finden. Man muss Kolonien auch erst aufbauen, bevor diese groß genug werden, um profitable Routen einzurichten. Hier ist dann Strategie gefragt: Welche Kolonien baue ich auf? Zahlen sich die anfänglichen Verluste in Zukunft aus? Was macht die Konkurrenz? usw. usw.

Das Spiel ist Early Access, somit ist klar, dass es noch über einige Kinderkrankheiten verfügt. Einige Bugs hat der Entwickler bereits am Releasetag gefixt. Das stimmt mich positiv für die weitere Entwicklung.
Für de aktuellen Preis auf jeden Fall zu empfehlen, wenn man den Entwickler unterstützen und an der weiteren Entwicklung teilhaben möchte. Auch sind die Chancen sehr gut, dass eigene Ideen und Vorschläge vom Entwickler aufgegriffen werden, wovon ihr euch selber überzeugen könnt. Also haut rein und happy trading! ;)

review:
Very promising game that can be enjoyed for hours as is, with active development. 

Planets and routes are not fire and forget, as they mature their needs change which needs update, least you run into debt and inefficient routes. As there are multiple planets to settle in the starting system alone, you will be kept busy modifying creating and deleting new routes. You can develop the planets from tiny expeditions with a dirt landing to multi dozen milion populations with interstellar ports and industry.

This game released on EA on 16th of August, and has already seen its first patch based on community feedback. It is still not without its bugs, but as far as EA goes, its very stable and has sufficient content to keep you koing. It needs only few minor tweak to be enjoyable for a very long time (think dozens of hours) at which point you will easily get your money's worth out of this game.

Some things that seem to be missing and might reimain for some time, is customization, more in depth economy and late game balance. AI needs work too (tho it might have actually been partially fixed today), but the developers are very open minded and responsive to feedback.

If you are still unsure, put the game on your watch list, as more tweaks patches and updates are said to be dropped in next few weeks; check youtube for some lets plays to give you a better idea on what you can expect.

Well, to start off, I would like to say that this dev team, however large they might be (At least 2 people based ion my interactions with them), is heads and tails above the rest. That is to to say, these guys are making a fun game, and thus far, have interacted with the community in an upbeat way while taking the criticism in stride, without getting defensive and argu  ing withe the players. It is no secret that I had a major issue with the game upon the early access release, and while the devs didn't see how that was possible, they  workd with me right away, to try to find a solution.. It took about 24 hours for them to diagnose the problem, and about another hour or so to release a patch that fixed the issue, from my recollation.
 
      So Steam doesn't give reviewers the opportunnnnity score a game from 1 to 10, but that doesn't mean we can't have a little fun and add something in. So based on Early Accesss games, I would give this game a 9/10. The only reason I wouldn't give this game a 10/10, is because I believe there is 1 other early accessgame available that is tiny bit vetter. 

     Now I could  probably simg the praises of this game al day, but I spent several hours playing this game, and I did that trying to find bugs. The initial game-breaking bug not withstanding, there are a few minor hiccups, and the ai still needs some work, but over all I had ro be pretty nitpicky to find much to put in the bugs and other issues section. The devs have also said they plan many new features that I can't wait for.

  So inc closing, I want to say that I have seen what this game has to offer, and the price is rather low for the hours of fun it will provide. You should buy this game, support these devs that have their act together, have produced a very fun game already, and are making it better and better what seems like every day. These are the types of devs that Early Access was meant for, and we need to let Steam know that this is what we expect from an earlly  access title and development team. One of the best ways to do that, is to pony up, and purchase this game as oon as possible.


TLDR::// I give the game a 9/10 compared to other early access games. You need to support these devs and get this game asap. It is fun with few bugs, and massive  developer support adding new features that look awesome. BUY THIS GAME!

review:
This game has it's share of rough edges and could use with more of a tutorial, but underneath there is a really great trading simulator that is a lot of fun.

Watch my MP Game with the developers as they prepare for release:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ulyfb4AwiA0

I had a lot of trouble making money until I started a new game and just watched to see what the AI did. Then it all sort of made sense to me. You need to be very careful about not running too many ships on a route, they will make some money at first but will quickly go into the red. Be sure to regularly check on all of your ship profitablility and make sure you sell off ships that are losing cash.  

The developers are very active and listen to the community and are hard at work balancing the game and adding changes to the UI etc. I am really confident in them and look forward to seeing all that they will bring to this really fun genre! 

If you're not ready for an Early Access game, then hold off on purchasing this, but if you're ready to deal with the issues you see in the first launch of an EA game then give it a shot! It's a ton of fun.
